Sec. 2.18. - TRANSPORTATION EXPENSES OF OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES—EXPENSES OTHER THAN FOR TRANSPORTATION: 
The provisions of this Article shall not be construed to preclude reimbursement for expenses incurred by officers and employees of the City in the performance of their official duties when such expenses are other than, or in addition to, expenses based upon mileage transportation costs. 
(Ord. No. 960, § 5)  
Sec. 2.19. - STATE AID TO PEACE OFFICERS AND PUBLIC SAFETY DISPATCHERS: 
The City Council declares that it desires that the City be qualified to receive aid from the State under the provisions of section 13522, chapter 1 of title 4, part 4, of the California Penal Code. 
Pursuant to section 13510(c) of the California Penal Code, the City, while receiving aid from the State pursuant to the aforesaid chapter 1 of title 4, part 4, will adhere to standards for recruitment and training established by the California Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training. 
Pursuant to section 13512 of the California Penal Code, the commission and its representatives may make such inquiries as deemed appropriate by the commission to ascertain that the City's peace officer and public safety dispatcher personnel adhere to those standards for selection and training established by the commission on peace officer standards and training. 
(Ord. No. 978, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1975, § 1, 8-8-1988)  
Sec. 2.20. - COUNCIL MEETINGS—REGULAR: 
A.  Regular meetings of the Council shall be held on the first, second, and fourth Monday of each month, except when such Monday is a holiday as defined by the personnel rules and regulations of the City (excluding the provisions for administrative holidays). 
B.  Regular meetings of the Council shall be held at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. in the City Council Chambers, City Hall, 1017 Middlefield Road, Redwood City, California. 
C.  All Council meetings shall be open to the public except for permitted executive sessions. 
(Ord. No. 1075, § 1; Ord. No. 1270, § 1; Ord. No. 1300, § 1; Ord. No. 1548, § 1, 9-18-1972; Ord. No. 1602, § 1, 6-10-1974; Ord. No. 1758, § 1, 6-26-1978; Ord. No. 1799, § 1, 9-17-1979; Ord. No. 2126, § 1, 7-14-1997; Ord. No. 2205 § 1, 12-4-2000) 
State Law reference— Council meetings, Gov. C., §§ 54950-54957.  
Sec. 2.21. - COUNCIL MEETINGS—ADJOURNED: 
The Council may adjourn any regular, adjourned regular, special or adjourned special meeting to a time and place specified in the order of adjournment. Less than a quorum may so adjourn from time to time. If all members are absent from any regular or adjourned regular meeting, the City Clerk or Deputy City Clerk may declare and order the meeting adjourned to a stated time and place. When a regular or adjourned regular meeting is adjourned as provided in this Section, the resulting meeting is a regular meeting for all purposes. When an order of adjournment of any meeting fails to state the hour or place at which the adjourned meeting is to be held, it shall be held at the hour and place specified for regular meetings by the preceding section. 
Any hearing being held or noticed or ordered to be held by the Council at any meeting may, by order or notice of continuance, be continued or recontinued to any subsequent meeting of the Council in the same manner and to the same extent as set forth in this Section for the adjournment of meetings; provided that if the hearing is continued to a time less than twenty-four (24) hours after the time specified in the order or notice of hearing, a copy of the order or notice of continuance of hearing shall be posted immediately following the meeting at which the order or notice of continuance was adopted. 
(Ord. No. 926, § 2; Ord. No. 1220, § 1) 
State Law reference— Adjourned meetings, Gov. C., § 54955.  
Sec. 2.22. - COUNCIL MEETINGS—SPECIAL: 
A special meeting may be called at any time by the Mayor, or by a majority of the members of the Council. On such call the City Clerk shall issue written notice thereof which shall be delivered personally, or by mail, to each member of the Council, the City Manager, the City Attorney, and to each newspaper of general circulation, radio or television station which has filed with the City Clerk a written request for such notice. Such notice must be delivered personally or by mail at least twenty-four (24) hours before the time of the meeting as specified in the notice. The notice shall specify the time and place of the special meeting and the business to be transacted. No other business shall be considered at such meetings by the Council. Such written notice may be dispensed with as to any member who at, or prior to, the time the meeting convenes, files with the City Clerk or Mayor a written waiver of notice. Such waiver may be given by telegram. Written notice may also be dispensed with as to any member who is actually present at the meeting at the time it convenes. 
(Ord. No. 926, § 3) 
State Law reference— Special meetings, Gov. C., § 54956.  
Sec. 2.23. - MEETINGS OF PLANNING COMMISSION: 
Unless notice is otherwise provided, regular meetings of the Planning Commission of the City of Redwood City shall be held at City Hall, 1017 Middlefield Road, Redwood City, on the days and at the hour designated by the Planning Commission by resolution adopted by such body and all such meetings shall be open to the public. Any meetings of the Planning Commission may be cancelled in advance by order of the Commission entered upon the minutes thereof. If the meeting is so cancelled, the secretary of the Planning Commission shall forward written notice thereof to each member of the Commission and to such other persons that request such notice and have filed their names and addresses with the secretary of the Planning Commission, unless such notice is waived in writing or unless the member in question is present at the meeting. Failure of any Commission member or any other person to receive notice of cancellation or of a change of meeting location shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the action of the Commission in cancelling the meeting. The provisions of Sections 2.21 and 2.22 of this Article relative to adjourned and special meetings of the Council shall be applicable to and shall govern the Planning Commission with the following modifications: the term "Commission" shall be substituted for the term "Council"; the term "chairman of the Planning Commission" shall be substituted for the term "Mayor"; the term "secretary of the Planning Commission" shall be substituted for the term "City Clerk"; and the term "Planning Director" shall be substituted for the term "Deputy City Clerk". 
(Ord. No. 926, § 4; Ord. No. 1548, § 2, 9-18-1972; Ord. No. 1602, § 2, 2-10-1974; Ord. No. 2284, § 1, 7-25-05)  
Sec. 2.24. - ISSUANCE AND SIGNATURES OF CHECKS AND WARRANTS DRAWN ON CITY FUNDS: 
A.  Pursuant to the provisions of section 59 of the Charter of the City, the City Manager and City Treasurer are hereby designated and authorized as the proper City officers to issue and sign all warrants and checks including checks, warrants and orders for payment of bond interest and redemption for outstanding bonds of Parking District No. 1. All such warrants and checks withdrawing City funds on deposit in the City treasury or on deposit in any banking institution, whether such funds be in active or inactive accounts, shall be issued and signed by both the City Manager and the City Treasurer. 
B.  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection A above, the Assistant City Manager is hereby designated and authorized to issue and sign all warrants and checks of the City on behalf of the City Manager in the absence or disability of the City Manager, and the Deputy City Treasurer is hereby designated and authorized to issue and sign all warrants and checks of the City on behalf of the City Treasurer in the absence or disability of the City Treasurer. 
C.  The signatures of the City officers authorized to issue and sign warrants and checks of the City as designated herein may be affixed or imposed upon such warrants or checks by facsimile signature check writing machine. Any and all banking institutions which have been furnished a copy of such facsimile signature and which have on deposit funds of the City are hereby authorized to honor any and all checks and warrants bearing the facsimile signature imposed by such machine as such facsimile signature is set forth on the copy thereof on file with such bank. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1)  
Sec. 2.25. - ASSIGNMENT FOR COLLECTION OF DEBTS TO CITY: 
The City Collector is hereby authorized to assign for collection all indebtedness due to the City when, after due diligence on the part of the City Collector, it appears that the indebtedness will remain unpaid unless special proceedings are instituted to enforce payment. 
No assignment for collection shall be made except to persons or firms licensed by the State of California Department of Professional and Vocational Standards pursuant to the provisions of section 6850, et seq., of the Business and Professions Code. 
(Ord. No. 1125, § 1)  
Sec. 2.26. - SEMIMONTHLY PAY PERIOD FOR CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES: 
Pursuant to Section 59 of the Charter of the City, a biweekly period is hereby prescribed for the allowance and payment of warrants for salaries of officers and employees. Such biweekly pay period shall be that interval of time during which officers and employees perform services on behalf of the City for which they are later compensated. 
(Ord. No. 1652, § 1, 10-6-75; Ord. No. 1659, §§ 1, 2, 1-5-76; Ord. No. 1781, § 1, 5-21-79)  
Sec. 2.27. - TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS—WHEN APPROVAL REQUIRED BEFORE DEPARTURE: 
Whenever a member of the City Council is required to travel from the City to a destination outside the City in the performance of his official duties, prior to departure of such member approval of the Council for such travel shall be required when any one or more of the following circumstances exist: 
A.  The destination is outside the State; 
B.  The destination is in excess of seventy-five (75) miles from the City; 
C.  The purpose for which travel is required necessitates the use of overnight living accommodations. 
Council approval, when granted, shall be deemed to include approval of advance for, or reimbursement of, expenses under Section 2.27.2. 
(Ord. No. 1348, § 1; Ord. No. 1404, § 1, 5-26-69)  
Sec. 2.27.1. - TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS—APPROVAL BEFORE DEPARTURE NOT REQUIRED UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS: 
Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 2.27, whenever a member of the City Council is required to travel from the City to a destination outside the City in the performance of his official duties, prior to departure of such member approval of the Council for such travel and advance for, or reimbursement of expenses under Section 2.27.2 shall not be required when any one or more of the following circumstances exist: 
A.  The destination is seventy-five (75) miles or less from the City; 
B.  Funds for expenses relating to the purpose for which travel is required have been appropriated in the current annual budget; 
C.  Prior to departure of such member, approval of the Council is required under Section 2.27 and extraordinary or unusual circumstances exist which make such approval impractical or extremely difficult to obtain; provided, however, that under such circumstances, prior to departure of such member, approval of the Mayor shall be required, and upon return from the destination requiring such travel the Council may approve reimbursement of expenses under Section 2.27.2 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1348, § 1)  
Sec. 2.27.2. - TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS—RATES FOR REIMBURSEMENT: 
Advance for, or reimbursement of expenses of a member of the Council necessarily and properly to be incurred or incurred in the performance of official duties shall be allowed as follows: 
A.  Actual transportation expenses to and from destination shall be allowed, but shall not exceed a maximum computed at twenty cents ($0.20) per mile for miles actually travelled outside the City by carrier service or any privately owned conveyance; provided, however, that air travel to and from destination in excess of three hundred (300) miles said maximum shall not, exceed actual air coach fare when such fare is less than the amount computed at the aforementioned rate. Notwithstanding the foregoing, should the Internal Revenue Service of the United States Department of the Treasury specify, as an automobile expense business deduction for federal income tax purposes, a standard mileage rate higher than the above mileage rate, said higher rate shall be allowed and substituted for said above rate. 
B.  All other customary, reasonable and necessary expenses shall be reimbursed at the actual cost therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1348, § 1; Ord. No. 1404, § 2, 5-26-69; Ord. No. 1575, § 3, 8-13-73; Ord. No. 1579, § 1, 9-17-73; Ord. No. 1699, § 2, 3-14-77; Ord. No. 1712, § 1, 7-18-77; Ord. No. 1829, § 2, 11-3-80; Ord. No. 1832, § 1, 11-24-80)  
Sec. 2.27.3. - TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS—INSIDE CITY: 
Whenever a member of the City Council desires to attend a function of a civic body, group, or organization within the City, and further desires advance for or reimbursement of actual expenses, excluding transportation, necessarily and properly to be incurred or incurred in such attendance, prior to such attendance approval of the Council shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 1348, § 1)  
Sec. 2.27.4. - TRAVEL EXPENSES FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS—REQUESTS FOR ADVANCE OR REIMBURSEMENT: 
Requests for an advance or reimbursement of expenses under Section 2.27.2 or Section 2.27.3 shall be made upon such forms as may be specified by the City Auditor. Said requests shall be submitted to the City Manager in duplicate, one copy of which shall be kept by the City as a permanent record and the other copy shall be returned to the payee together with the City's warrant issued pursuant to said request. A copy of each such request produced by a suitable copying process shall be delivered to each member of the Council prior to submission thereof to the Council for approval. 
(Ord. No. 1348, § 1)  
Sec. 2.27.5. - ITEMS OF EXPENSE TO BE ACCOUNTED FOR BY RECEIPT: 
Each item of expense for which request for advance or reimbursement is made under Section 2.27.4 shall be reported by receipt, voucher, or other appropriate document within thirty (30) days of the date upon which such expense was incurred; provided, however, that any expense item less than ten dollars ($10.00) need not be so supported; and, provided, further, that such receipt, voucher or other appropriate document shall be required in accounting for transportation expenses (excluding transportation by private conveyance) irrespective of the amount of such expense. 
(Ord. No. 1348, § 1; Ord. No. 1404, § 3, 5-26-69; Ord. No. 1579, § 2, 9-17-73; Memo 3-11-94)  
Sec. 2.27.6. - GENERAL MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS: 
A.  Pursuant to the provisions of Elections Code Sections 1301 and 10403.5, made applicable by Section 4 of the Charter of the City of Redwood City, this Council does hereby require and order that general municipal elections of the City of Redwood City shall be held in said City on the same day as statewide general elections as specified in Section 1200 of the Elections Code, to wit: the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each even-numbered year, commencing with said election in November, 2018, and continuing thereafter so long as this Section shall remain in effect. 
B.  This Council hereby finds and determines that, as a result of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived, no term of office of any elective officer of this City shall be increased or decreased by more than twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 2078, §§ 1, 2, 4-11-94; Ord. No. 2433, § 3, 3-13-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2078, §§ 1, 2, adopted April 11, 1994, was not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, those provisions have been included as § 2.27.6.  
Sec. 2.27.7. - CITY COUNCIL DISTRICT ELECTIONS: 
A.  Declaration of Purpose. The City Council hereby declares that the change of method of electing members of this Council hereby enacted is being made in furtherance of the California Voting Rights Act of 2001. 
B.  City Council Districts Established. Seven (7) City Council districts are hereby established in the City of Redwood City. The boundaries and identifying number of each district shall be as described on the Council District Map as shown below. 
C.  Election of Members of the City Council by District. 
1.  Following the effective date of the ordinance from which this Section is derived and upon the commencement of "by district" elections in the order established in Section 2.D of this Code, members of the City Council shall be elected "by district" as defined in California Government Code Section 34871 or any successor statute. Any candidate for City Council must have been a resident and elector of the district in which he or she seeks election for at least thirty (30) days before the time he or she files nominating papers or equivalent declaration of candidacy for such office, or such person's appointment to fill a vacancy therein. No term of any member of the City Council that commenced prior to the effective date of this Section shall be affected by the adoption of this Section. 
2.  Registered voters signing nomination papers or voting for a member of the City Council shall be residents of the geographical area making up the district from which the member is to be elected. 
3.  The terms of the office of each member elected to the City Council shall remain four (4) years. 
D.  Commencement of District Elections. Commencing on the general municipal election in 2020 and every four (4) years thereafter the voters in districts 1, 3, 4, and 7 shall elect members of the City Council by district for full four (4) year terms. At the general municipal election in 2022 and every four (4) years thereafter, the voters in districts 2, 5, and 6 shall elect members of the City Council by district for full four (4) year terms. 
The term of office of any Council member who has been elected and whose term of office has not expired shall not be affected by any change in the boundaries of the district from which he or she was elected. 
  
(Ord. No. 2463, § 1, Exh. A, 5-20-19)  
Sec. 2.27.8. - NOTICE OF HEARING ON BUDGET: 
At least ten (10) days prior to the public hearing on the budget, the Deputy Treasurer shall publish a notice of the public hearing on the budget on the City of Redwood City's Public Notices webpage. 
At least ten (10) days prior to the public hearing on the budget, the Deputy Treasurer shall post a notice of public hearing on the budget at City Hall and at all branches of the Redwood City Library, consistent with the posting of regular and special agendas of meetings of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2457, §§ 2, 3, 2-11-19)  
ARTICLE II. - COPIES OR EXTRACTS OF PUBLIC RECORDS 
 
Secs. 2.28—2.31. - RESERVED:  
Sec. 2.31.1. - CITY CLERK TO PREPARE ON DEMAND: 
The City Clerk, upon demand of any person, shall prepare copies or extracts from any public record of the City in accordance with the provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1)  
Sec. 2.31.2. - OFFICER HAVING UNFILED RECORD TO FURNISH IT TO CITY CLERK: 
In the event the public record is not on file with the City Clerk, the officer having custody of the record shall furnish it to the City Clerk for the purpose of preparing the copy or extract. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 2)  
Sec. 2.31.3. - PROCEDURE WHEN CITY CLERK UNABLE TO MAKE COPY: 
In the event the record is of a nature that cannot be copied by the City Clerk, the Clerk may cause the copies to be prepared by another government agency or by any firm engaged in the business of preparing such copies. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 4)  
Sec. 2.31.4. - CITY COUNCIL TO ESTABLISH FEES: 
Fees for the preparation of copies or extracts of public records, certifying to copies thereof or providing other documents in the Clerk's custody shall be established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 3; Ord. No. 2022, § 2, 7-9-90)  
Sec. 2.31.5. - RESERVED: 
Editor's note— Former § 2.31.5 pertained to the fee for a certified copy, was repealed by § 1 of Ord. No. 2022, adopted July 9, 1990, and originated from § 5 of Ord. No. 1038.  
Sec. 2.31.6. - FEES—EXEMPTIONS FROM PAYMENT: 
No fee shall be charged by the Clerk for services rendered in connection with a criminal action. 
No fee shall be charged by the Clerk for service rendered to any municipality or county or the State or United States Government. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 6)  
Sec. 2.31.7. - FEES—ADVANCE PAYMENT OR DEPOSIT OF ESTIMATED FEE MAY BE REQUIRED: 
The Clerk may require any person requesting the preparation of a copy or extract to pay the fee therefor in advance or deposit the amount of the estimated fee in the event the fee cannot be determined. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 7)  
ARTICLE III. - INVESTMENT OF PUBLIC MONIES 
 
Secs. 2.32, 2.33. - RESERVED: 
Editor's note— Sections 2.32 and 2.33 were repealed by Ord. No. 1081.  
Sec. 2.33.1. - AUTHORITY OF CITY TREASURER TO INVEST UNENCUMBERED FUNDS: 
Pursuant to the provisions of Section 34 of the Charter of the City, the City Treasurer is hereby authorized to invest such public monies of the City as are not required for immediate expenditure in such securities or other certificates of indebtedness as are provided by law for the investment of public funds, generally. Such authority shall include the power to sell or exchange such securities and reinvest the proceeds thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1065, § 1; Ord. No. 1776, § 1, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 2.33.2. - REPORT OF AUTHORIZED TRANSACTIONS REQUIRED: 
The City Treasurer shall make a detailed written report to the Council of all investment transactions authorized by this Article on the last day of each calendar month during which any public monies are so invested. 
(Ord. No. 1065, § 2)  
Sec. 2.33.3. - RESPONSIBILITY OF CITY TREASURER FOR TRANSACTIONS: 
In the event the authority granted by this Article is exercised, the City Treasurer shall assume full responsibility for the transactions, authorized hereunder until such authority is revoked by this Council. 
(Ord. No. 1065, § 3)  
ARTICLE IV. - FUNDS 
 
Sec. 2.34. - REFERENCE TO FUNDS NOT SET OUT IN ARTICLE: 
In addition to the funds established in this Article, reference is made to the following provisions of this Code: 
A.  Section 16.3-Library Fund. 
B.  Section 27.70-Sewer Fund. 
C.  Section 38.20-Water Fund. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 2; Ord. No. 1402, § 1, 5-19-69; Ord. No. 1403, § 1, 5-19-69)  
Sec. 2.35. - RESERVED: 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1402, § 2, enacted May 19, 1969, repealed § 2.35, derived from Ord. No. 1137, § 3, pertaining to the water fund. Provisions relating to the water fund are currently set out in § 38.20.  
Sec. 2.36. - EQUIPMENT SERVICE FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Equipment Service Fund" is hereby established. All monies allocated to such fund shall be appropriated or expended for the operation and maintenance of equipment owned by the City, the replacement of worn out or out-moded equipment of said City, or the acquisition of new equipment for said City. As used herein, the term "equipment" shall include, but not be limited to, vehicles of all kinds, heavy duty equipment or machinery, watercraft, construction equipment, office equipment and machines, electrical and electronic machines and devices, fixtures, furnishings, furniture, and other capital items of similar or like character. 
All amounts paid from the Equipment Service Fund for the purposes hereinabove stated shall be reimbursed to said fund by the particular account, fund, or activity benefited by such payment. Such reimbursement shall be made at such time, and during such periods, as funds are available therefor in such particular account, fund, or activity so benefited. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 4; Ord. No. 1535, § 1, 6-26-72)  
Sec. 2.37. - DOCKTOWN MARINA MANAGEMENT FUND: 
An enterprise fund to be known as the "Docktown Marina Management Fund" is hereby established. All moneys received by the City of Redwood City from tenants and other sources for the operations and maintenance of the Docktown Marina shall be deposited in the Docktown Marina Management Fund and shall be expended solely for the following purposes in the order set forth: 
(a)  For the payment of utility invoices from public utility companies; 
(b)  For the payment of license or other fees supporting access and the operations of the marina; 
(c)  For the payment of maintenance and operations costs, including but not limited to contracted employees, salaries, benefits, material, design internal service charges, insurance, and construction of necessary improvements; and 
(d)  For the control and management of slip rental deposits and other fees and charges required by Council approved Berthing Agreements. 
For the purpose of complying with the obligations associated with utility accounts and other operations and maintenance requirements, City shall periodically fix and prescribe fees, rentals, and other charges for the services and use of the Docktown Marina facilities sufficient to produce gross revenues adequate for the following purposes in the order set forth: 
(a)  Payment of all installments for contracted capital work; and 
(b)  Payment of all expenses of operation, maintenance, and repair of said facility. 
(Ord. No. 2392, § 2, 3-11-13)  
Sec. 2.38. - ART IN PUBLIC PLACES FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Art in Public Places Fund" is hereby established. 
In establishing this fund, the City Council finds and declares the following: (a) public art is a valuable means of promoting vibrancy, defining cultural uniqueness, building community, and improving the quality of life in the City; (b) the environment, image, and character of the City would be improved by public art; (c) public art helps make cities more livable and more visually stimulating; (d) the presence of and access to public art enlivens the public areas of buildings and their grounds and makes them more welcoming; (d) public art can illuminate the diversity and history of a community, create/nurture/promote positive community interactions and conversation, and foster the economic development of the community. 
To further the forgoing [foregoing] goals, the "Art in Public Places Fund" is established to fund the provision of public art within the City. Monies in this fund may be deposited through contributions from the City's Capital Outlay Fund or any other source authorized in Chapter 45 of this Code. Works of public art shall be acquired and installed pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 45 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2424, § 1, 6-27-16)  
Sec. 2.39. - INDEMNITY FUND: 
A special fund to be known as "Indemnity Fund" is hereby created. All monies received by the City as indemnity, reimbursement, or settlement for the loss or damage of any City property, from an insurance company or from any other source, shall be credited to the Indemnity Fund. All monies maintained in the Indemnity Fund in accordance with the provisions of this Section shall be expended for the sole purpose of, and are hereby appropriated for, the repair or replacement of the particular damaged or destroyed City property for which such monies were received. 
All monies not expended pursuant to the provisions of this Section within six (6) months of the credit thereof to the Indemnity Fund shall be, and the same are hereby ordered, transferred from the Indemnity Fund to the unbudgeted, unappropriated reserve of the General Fund. 
The Council may, by resolution, transfer at any time any monies deposited in the Indemnity Fund pursuant to this Section to the General Fund or to any existing appropriated item. 
(Ord. No. 969, §§ 1, 2)  
Sec. 2.40. - SPECIAL DEPOSIT FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Special Deposit Fund" is hereby created. All monies received to enforce or to secure the faithful performance of any obligation toward the City shall be deposited in such fund and shall be expended solely to refund amounts properly refundable upon termination of the obligation or to satisfy the obligation in such manner otherwise provided by law or agreement. All monies contributed to the City shall be deposited in such fund pending acceptance. All monies the nature and purpose of which cannot be ascertained at the time of receipts shall be deposited in such fund. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 5)  
Sec. 2.41. - RETIREMENT FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Retirement Fund" is hereby established. All monies collected or received for the purpose of providing the City's contribution towards employees' retirement shall be deposited in this fund. The monies in this fund shall be expended solely for the payment of the City's cost of providing retirement benefits for the employees of the City. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 6)  
Sec. 2.41.1. - CAPITAL OUTLAY FUND: 
A "Capital Outlay Fund" is hereby established. All monies set aside and allocated to the Capital Outlay Fund may be appropriated or expended only for capital outlay purposes. As used herein, the phrase "capital outlay purposes" shall include all expenditures necessary or convenient for the planning, designing, acquisition, construction and completion of public works and improvements and the acquisition of real property or interests therein, including the payment of principal and interest installments on bonds issued for the acquisition and construction of public works and improvements, and including the leasing of real property and improvements thereon when such lease includes the right of purchase. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 7; Ord. No. 1258, § 1; Ord. No. 1535, § 2, 6-26-72)  
Sec. 2.41.2. - FEDERAL REVENUE SHARING FUND: 
A special fund to be known as "Federal Revenue Sharing Fund" is hereby established. All monies received from the United States Government pursuant to the State and Local Fiscal Assistance Act of 1972 (Title I of P.L. 92-512) shall be deposited in said fund, and shall be expended solely for the purposes and in accordance with the provisions of said act and all regulations and directives relating thereto issued by the Federal government. 
(Ord. No. 1563, § 1, 4-23-73)  
Sec. 2.41.3. - SPECIAL GAS TAX STREET IMPROVEMENT FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Special Gas Tax Street Improvement Fund" is hereby established pursuant to section 2113 of the Streets and Highways Code. All monies received by the City from the State under the provisions of sections 2106 and 2107 of the Streets and Highways Code shall be deposited in said Fund. All monies in said Fund shall be expended exclusively for the purposes authorized by and shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 3 (commencing at section 2100) division 5, Streets and Highways Code. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 9; Memo 3-11-1994)  
Sec. 2.41.4. - TRAFFIC SAFETY FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Traffic Safety Fund" is hereby established. All monies received by the City from the State pursuant to the provisions of section 42200 of the Vehicle Code shall be deposited in such Fund and shall be expended solely for the purposes stated in such section 42200. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 10)  
Sec. 2.41.5. - ASSESSMENT DISTRICT REVOLVING FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Assessment District Revolving Fund" is hereby established. All monies allocated to such Fund shall be expended solely for the payment of the costs and expenses of expert personal services of an engineering, appraisal, property acquisition and legal nature and for the acquisition of property necessary or convenient for the completion of public works and improvements within assessment districts pending the formation of and sale of bonds by such assessment districts as are authorized to be instituted by the Council. All amounts paid from such Fund shall be reimbursed to it by the particular special assessment district benefited at such time as funds are available through the sale of bonds by the benefited district. 
(Ord. No. 1137, § 11)  
Sec. 2.41.6. - MUNICIPAL TRANSIT FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Municipal Transit Fund" is hereby created. All monies received from the operation of a transit system owned or operated by the City shall be deposited in such Fund together with such additional funds as may be from time to time appropriated hereto. The monies in this Fund shall be expended solely for the operation, maintenance and management of a transit system and related facilities, including the acquisition of vehicles and the construction of permanent transit system facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1330, § 1)  
Sec. 2.41.7. - RESERVED:  
Sec. 2.41.8. - DOWNTOWN PARKING AND BUSINESS IMPROVEMENT AREA FUND: 
A special fund designated "Downtown Parking and Business Improvement Area Fund" is hereby established. All monies collected or received from the levy of the assessment imposed pursuant to any ordinance, or amendment thereof, establishing a parking and business improvement area within the City pursuant to part 6 (commencing with § 36500), division 18, Streets and Highways Code of the State of California, shall be deposited in said Fund and shall be expended solely for the purposes set forth in the ordinance establishing such area. 
(Ord. No. 1364, § 1, 6-17-1968; Memo 3-11-1994)  
Sec. 2.41.9. - SELF-INSURANCE TRUST FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Self-Insurance Trust Fund" is hereby established. All monies allocated to such Fund shall be appropriated or expended solely for the purpose of payment of the City's costs related to the maintenance and operation of self-insured workers' compensation, general liability, crime and property insurance programs, including, but not limited to: expenses involving administrative and claims support services, legal services, safety engineering services, claims liability and excess insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1677, § 1, 8-9-1976; Ord. No. 1711, § 1, 7-11-1977)  
Sec. 2.41.10. - SIDNEY D. HERKNER MEMORIAL TRUST FUND: 
A special fund designated "Sidney D. Herkner Memorial Trust Fund" is hereby established. All monies received by the City from contributions by the public for the purposes for which a bequest has been made to the City from the will of Sidney D. Herkner shall be deposited in such Fund and shall be expended solely for the purposes stated in such will. 
(Ord. No. 1726, § 1, 11-21-1977)  
Sec. 2.41.11. - INTERNAL SERVICES FUND: 
A special fund to be known as the "Internal Services Fund" is hereby established. All monies allocated to such Fund shall be appropriated or expended solely for building services, data services, communications, duplicating services, providing supplies and storage and similar central services programs or activities which directly serve operating departments. 
All amounts paid from this Fund for the purposes herein specified shall be reimbursed to said Fund by the particular account, fund or activity benefited by such payment. Such reimbursement shall be made at such time, and during such periods, as funds are available therefor in such particular account, fund or activity so benefited. 
(Ord. No. 1854, § 1, 12-14-1981)  
Sec. 2.41.12. - SUPPLEMENTAL LAW ENFORCEMENT SERVICES FUND: 
A special fund designated the "Supplemental Law Enforcement Services Fund" is hereby established pursuant to the provisions of chapter 6.7 (commencing with § 30061), division 3, title 3, of the Government Code. All monies received by the City from the State pursuant to the provisions of said chapter shall be deposited in said Fund. Upon consideration and determination on the question of approval of written requests by the Chief of Police for expenditure of said monies, and following public hearing on said question, the Council shall appropriate and expend said monies for "front line" Municipal police services. Appropriations from the Fund shall supplement existing front line law enforcement services, and shall not be used to supplant any existing funding for law enforcement services. 
(Ord. No. 2115, § 1, 10-7-1996)  
Sec. 2.41.13. - SECTION 115 TRUST ACCOUNT FUND: 
A fiduciary fund to be known as the "Section 115 Trust Account Fund" is hereby established. The City Council has designated an initial deposit of ten million five hundred forty-eight thousand eight hundred fifty dollars ($10,548,850.00) into the Section 115 Trust Account Fund from the General Fund, the Enterprise Funds, and the Internal Services Funds. These monies and any additional funding amounts to be determined in the future must be dedicated solely for the following purposes set forth: 
A.  For pre-funding pension obligations; 
B.  For acting as a reserve fund to help the City pay for increasing annual CalPERS contribution requirements; and 
C.  For providing more local control and flexibility in investment allocations compared to maintaining funds in a City-invested reserve or giving money to CalPERS to pay down the unfunded liability. 
The City Manager, or his/her successor or designee, is appointed as the City's Plan Administrator solely for the following purposes set forth: 
A.  For the administration of the Trust; 
B.  For executing an "Agreement for Professional Services" (to include consulting and investment services) between the City and an entity authorized to offer Section 115 trusts that has been approved by the City Council; and 
C.  For the investment of Trust funds that utilize an investment strategy consistent with recommendations provided by the City Council's Finance/Audit Sub-Committee. 
The decision to add additional funds to the Trust or to disburse funds from the Trust in future fiscal years would be subject to the following provisions: 
A.  Annual evaluation of the performance of the investments of the Trust; 
B.  Analysis of the City's year-end budget position and overall financial outlook; and 
C.  Approval by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2452, § 2, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 2.41.14. - OTHER RESTRICTED DONATIONS AND GRANTS FUND: 
A special revenue fund to be known as the "Other Restricted Donations and Grants Fund" is hereby established. Donations or other revenues received from businesses, organizations, or individuals for specific programs or for other purposes shall be deposited into this fund. The monies in this fund shall be expended solely in a manner that is consistent with the intention of the donor or the grantor of such monies. 
(Ord. No. 2452, § 2, 8-27-18)  
Sec. 2.41.15. - PEG FEES FUND: 
A capital projects fund to be known as the "PEG Fees Fund" is hereby established. Monies collected from cable operators in the City for the purpose of funding the costs of capital expenditures or operational equipment of PEG channel facilities (e.g., local access television channels) shall be deposited into said fund. The monies in this fund shall be expended solely for the payment of costs described above. 
(Ord. No. 2452, § 2, 8-27-18)  
ARTICLE V. - DISPOSITION AND ACQUISITION OF REAL PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 2.42. - [PURPOSE:] 
For the purpose of this Article, Surplus Land means the following: 
A.  "Land" means real property or a real property interest. 
B.  Subject to the exemptions or exclusions set forth in the state Surplus Land Act, (Cal. Government Code § 54220, et seq.) as it may be amended from time to time, "Surplus Land" means any Land that is not required to fulfill the mission of a City department, commission or agency with jurisdiction or control of such Land or that is not required to fulfill the mission of another governmental agency pursuant to an inter-governmental transfer. 
C.  The following is not "Surplus Land": 
1.  Land with a continuing obligation upon the land such as a parking covenant. 
2.  Land for which the City has a specific purpose even if it will not be used as a City facility. A specific purpose includes but is not limited to any of the following: 
a.  To dispose of the Land in such a way that the City secures certain community benefits which benefits may be defined by the City Council pursuant to a resolution at the time it approves a sale or other disposition of the Land; 
b.  To control the development of the land in order to serve the interests of the City; or 
c.  To control the development of the land in order to serve the common benefit which may include but is not limited to stimulating the growth and development of the City; to make Land available for affordable housing; to make Land available for a better or more compatible use; to diminish blight or redevelop an area; to sell the Land in order to increase City revenues; or to use the Land to accomplish an implementation of a General Plan objective, goal or policy. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 2, 3-24-14)  
Secs. 2.43—2.52. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VI. - UNCLAIMED PERSONAL PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2458, § 4(Exh. A), adopted Feb. 25. 2019, amended Art. VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VI, §§ 2.53—2.56, pertained to unclaimed property, and derived from Ord. No. 1437, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 1969; Ord. No. 1876, § 1, adopted Aug. 22, 1983; and Ord. No. 2039, § 1, adopted July 8, 1991. 
 
Sec. 2.53. - DELIVERY TO POLICE DEPARTMENT BY CITY PERSONNEL: 
Any money, goods, or other personal property found, recovered or held by, delivered to, or otherwise coming into the possession of an officer, employee, or agent of the City shall be delivered to the Police Department. The finder of such personal property shall give information concerning the time when and the place where the property was found, a description of the property, the circumstances under which it was found, and the name of the owner of the property, if known. 
(Ord. No. 2458, § 4(Exh. A), 2-25-19)  
Sec. 2.54. - DISPOSITION OF DANGEROUS OR PERISHABLE PERSONAL PROPERTY; PERSONAL PROPERTY GOVERNED BY FEDERAL LAW, VEHICLE OR PENAL CODES: 
All personal property in the possession of the Police Department, the disposition of which is governed by Federal law, or the Vehicle or Penal Codes of the State shall be disposed of according to such law or Codes. All such property which the Chief of Police determines to be dangerous or perishable may be disposed of immediately, without notice, in such manner as they determine to be in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 2458, § 4(Exh. A), 2-25-19)  
Sec. 2.55. - DISPOSITION OF PERSONAL PROPERTY NOT COVERED BY SECTION 2.54: 
Except as provided in Section 2.54 of this Article, unclaimed personal property in the possession of the Police Department shall be disposed of as follows: 
A.  The disposition of personal property, exclusive of money, shall be in accordance with California Civil Code Section 2080, et seq. and, in addition, shall be governed by the following provisions: 
1.  When a finder in whom title vests relinquishes their claim and interest in the personal property, the Chief of Police may sell at public auction or otherwise dispose of said property in whatever manner the Chief of Police deems to be in the public interest. 
2.  Any personal property with a value of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) which has been unclaimed for a period of at least ninety (90) days may, instead of being sold at public auction to the highest bidder pursuant to the provisions of Civil Code Section 2080.5, be relinquished to a probation officer, the Welfare Department of the County of San Mateo, or to any charitable or nonprofit organization which is authorized under its articles of incorporation to participate in a program or activity designed to prevent juvenile delinquency and which is exempt from income taxation under Federal or State law, or both, for use in any program or activity designed to prevent juvenile delinquency. Before any property is turned over to a probation officer, to the Welfare Department of the County of San Mateo, or to any charitable or nonprofit organization, the Police Department shall notify the owner, if their identity is known or can be reasonably ascertained, that the Police Department possesses the property, and where the property may be claimed. The owner may be notified by mail, telephone, or by means of a notice published in a newspaper of general circulation which the Chief of Police determines is most likely to give notice to the owner of the property. 
3.  Whenever the Chief of Police conducts a public auction for the purpose of selling unclaimed property in the possession of the Police Department, they shall give notice of the sale by publishing notice thereof once in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City, at least five (5) days before the time fixed for the sale. Such property shall be sold at public auction to the highest bidder. The proceeds shall be deposited in the General Fund of the City. In the event no bid is offered for such property, the property shall be disposed of by the Chief of Police in such manner as they determine to be in the public interest. 
B.  The disposition of unclaimed money shall be in accordance with California Government Code Section 50050, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2458, § 4(Exh. A), 2-25-19)  
Sec. 2.56. - SCHEDULE OF CHARGES: 
Pursuant California Civil Code Sections 2080 and 2080.1, the Chief of Police may require the owner to pay a reasonable charge to defray costs of storage and care of the personal property. The amount of the charge shall be established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 2458, § 4(Exh. A), 2-25-19)  
Secs. 2.57—2.62. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VII. - PURCHASING 
 
Sec. 2.63. - BIDDING REQUIRED FOR PURCHASES OR CONTRACTS OF MATERIALS, SERVICES, EQUIPMENT OR SUPPLIES EXCEEDING SIXTY THOUSAND DOLLARS AND PUBLIC WORKS OR IMPROVEMENT CONTRACTS: 
A.  All materials, personal services, equipment and supplies costing more than sixty thousand dollars ($60,000) exclusive of sales tax and freight, shall be purchased in the open market on the basis of competitive bidding in accordance with the provisions of this Article. 
B.  Any public work or improvement shall be contracted for in accordance with Section 67 of the Charter unless such work or improvement is performed by a department authorized to execute such work or improvement directly as provided in Section 67 or unless the work is performed as provided in Section 68 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 1; Ord. No. 1627, §§ 1, 2, 4-14-75; Ord. No. 1860, § 1, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 2238, § 1, 12-5-02; Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 5-24-04)  
Sec. 2.64. - DEPARTMENT HEAD TO SUBMIT SPECIFICATIONS OF MATERIAL, ETC., BEFORE PURCHASE: 
Before any contract for the purchase of any materials, equipment or supplies is advertised for bid, the department head for whom such materials, equipment or supplies are being purchased shall submit specifications therefor to the City Manager for approval. Such specifications shall include the type, quality, quantity and, whenever practicable, the date, place and method of delivery of the materials, equipment or supplies to be purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 2)  
Sec. 2.65. - SOLICITATION OF WRITTEN BIDS; PUBLICATION OF NOTICE FOR CERTAIN BIDS; CONTENTS OF SOLICITATION OR NOTICE: 
A.  The City Manager shall solicit written bids without public advertisement for every contract: 
1.  For any public work or improvement, the estimated cost of which is greater than ten thousand dollars ($10,000), but less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000); and 
2.  For the purchase of materials, personal services, equipment and supplies, the estimated cost of which is greater than ten thousand dollars ($10,000) but less than or equal to sixty thousand dollars ($60,000), exclusive of sales tax and freight. 
B.  Such solicitation shall be in writing, and shall be sent to not less than three (3) prospective bidders; provided, however, that where less than three (3) prospective bidders are known by the City Manager to exist, he/she shall send such solicitation to all those so known to him/her. 
C.  The City Manager shall cause public notice inviting bids to be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the City at least five (5) calendar days preceding the day set for the receipt of proposals for every contract for any public work or improvement equal to or greater than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000), and every contract for the purchase of materials, equipment or supplies, the estimated cost of which is greater than sixty thousand dollars ($60,000), exclusive of sales tax and freight. 
D.  The aforesaid written solicitation, or the public notice as appropriate, shall contain a general description of the public work or improvement to be done, or the articles to be purchased, shall state where the particular plans or specifications relating thereto may be secured, and shall state the time and place for opening of bids, or the time and place for competitive oral bidding before the City Council. Every solicitation and notice shall contain a reservation of the City Council's right to reject any and all bids. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 3; Ord. No. 1627, § 3, 4-14-75; Ord. No. 1860, § 2, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 2238, § 1, 12-5-02; Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 5-24-04)  
Sec. 2.66. - BIDDERS TO PROVIDE SECURITY WHEN REQUIRED; FORFEITURE OF SECURITY FOR FAILURE TO FULFILL CONTRACT, ETC.: 
When deemed necessary by the City Manager, bid security shall be prescribed in the public notice or written solicitation inviting bids. Such security shall be in the form of cash, a cashier's check, certified check or a bond executed by a corporate surety authorized to transact business in the State, whichever is deemed acceptable by the City Manager. A successful bidder shall forfeit any security required by the City Manager upon such bidder's failure to enter into a written contract or otherwise perform within ten (10) days after the notice of the award and submission of the contract to the bidder. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 4; Ord. No. 1627, § 4, 4-14-75)  
Sec. 2.67. - PROCEDURE FOR SUBMITTING, OPENING, ETC., SEALED BIDS; REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF CITY MANAGER: 
Unless the City Manager prescribes competitive oral bidding before the City Council in the written solicitation or the public notice inviting bids, bids shall be submitted in sealed envelopes to the City Manager and shall be identified as bids on the envelopes. 
Bids shall be opened publicly at the time and place stated in the written solicitation or the public notice inviting bids. 
The City Manager or the person opening the bids under the direction of the City Manager shall prepare a tabulation of all bids received, which tabulation shall be available for public inspection. 
The City Manager shall report on such bids at the next regular legislative meeting of the City Council and shall make his recommendations thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 5; Ord. No. 1627, § 5, 4-14-75)  
Sec. 2.68. - AWARD OF CONTRACT TO LOWEST RESPONSIBLE BIDDER; WAIVER OF IRREGULARITIES IN BIDS OR CORRECTION OF ERRONEOUS BIDS: 
A.  Award of Contract: Except as provided in subdivision B., every contract: 
1.  For any public work or improvement project costing more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000) but less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000), exclusive of sales tax and freight, shall be awarded by the City Manager to the lowest responsible bidder; 
2.  For any public work or improvement project costing one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) or more, exclusive of sales tax and freight, shall be awarded by the City Council to the lowest responsible bidder; 
3.  For the purchase of materials, personal services, equipment or supplies costing more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000) and less than or equal to sixty thousand dollars ($60,000), exclusive of sales tax and freight, shall be awarded by the City Manager to the lowest responsible bidder; and 
4.  For the purchase of materials, personal services, equipment or supplies costing more than sixty thousand dollars ($60,000), excluding sales tax and freight, shall be awarded by the City Council to the lowest responsible bidder. 
B.  Prequalification: For any public work or improvement project, the estimated cost of which is twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) or more, the City Manager may require from prospective bidders answers to questions contained in a standard form of prequalification questionnaire which, when completed, shall be submitted as a declaration under penalty of perjury. Advertisement of the invitation to prospective bidders to submit responses to the questionnaire with respect to any such project designated by the City Manager for the prequalification process shall be made in the manner of advertising public notice inviting bids. Said responses shall be submitted in sealed envelopes to the City Manager and shall be identified as responses to the prequalification questionnaire for the designated project. Whenever prequalification is required of any bidder for a contract, it shall be required for all prospective bidders for that contract. 
The standard form of prequalification questionnaire shall include, but not be limited to, questions pertaining to the following criteria: 
1.  The familiarity and experience of the prospective bidder with the particular type of public work or improvement project designated in the questionnaire; 
2.  The sufficiency of personnel, equipment, materials and other facilities or resources of the prospective bidder to accomplish the work of the designated project within the time specified, and in conformance to the specifications thereof; 
3.  The qualification and capacity of the prospective bidder to obtain, if required, performance and payment bonds in the amount of one hundred percent (100%) of the cost of the contract for the designated project from a bonding or security company licensed to do business in the State of California; 
4.  The financial condition of the prospective bidder; 
5.  The experience of the prospective bidder in performing public works contracts, generally, and public and private contracts for works or improvements similar to the designated project; 
6.  The safety record of the prospective bidder with respect to construction contracts; 
7.  The record of the prospective bidder within the five (5) year period next preceding the date of submittal of the questionnaire regarding disputes, claims filed, submittal of disputes to mediation, arbitration, or other dispute-resolving procedures, and litigation pertaining to prior public works or private construction projects; and 
8.  Such other information as the Manager shall determine relating to the ability, capacity and skill of the prospective bidder to perform the contract for the designated project. 
The Manager shall adopt and apply a uniform system of rating prospective bidders on the basis of the standard questionnaire submitted for a designated project. Based upon said system, those prospective bidders who or which qualify for bidding on the project shall be notified thereof in writing by the Manager and shall be invited to submit written, sealed bids in the manner provided in this Article for the submittal of bids following publication of public notice inviting bids; provided, that such publication shall not be required in the case of invitation to submit bids from prequalified bidders. 
C.  The Council shall have the power to reject any and all bids and solicit or advertise again, or invite bids from prequalified bidders again, or to provide for the work in question to be done pursuant to Section 68 of the Charter. 
The Council may waive any irregularities in bids received or permit the correction of erroneous bids when the Council finds that the irregularity or error was not the result of fraudulent intent on the part of the bidder and that the best interests of the public would be served thereby. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 6; Ord. No. 1627, § 6, 4-14-75; Ord. No. 1860, § 3, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 2104, § 1, 1-22-96; Ord. No. 2238, § 1, 12-5-02; Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 5-24-04)  
Sec. 2.69. - DETERMINATION OF LOWEST RESPONSIBLE BIDDER: 
In determining the "lowest responsible bidder," the following factors may be considered in addition to price: 
A.  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. 
B.  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder. 
C.  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services for the City or other contracting parties. 
D.  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with the laws and ordinances relating to a contract or service. 
E.  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the services. 
F.  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 7)  
Sec. 2.70. - PROCEDURE IN EVENT OF TIE BIDS: 
In the event two (2) or more bids received are for the same total amount or unit price, fitness, quality and all other factors being equal, preference shall be given to local bidders; otherwise, the order of preference shall be determined by the drawing of lots. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 8)  
Sec. 2.71. - PERFORMANCE BONDS: 
The written solicitation or the public notice inviting bids may prescribe that the successful bidder shall furnish a performance bond in such amount as the City Manager may find reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the City. Such bond shall be executed by a corporate surety authorized to do business in the State which is acceptable to the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 9; Ord. No. 1627, § 7, 4-14-75)  
Sec. 2.72. - EXECUTION IN WRITING OF CONTRACTS EXCEEDING TEN THOUSAND DOLLARS: 
All purchase contracts entered into by the City for the purchase of materials, personal services, equipment or supplies costing more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000), exclusive of sales tax and freight, and all contracts for the performance of any public work or improvement shall be in writing and shall be executed by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 10, Ord. No. 1627, § 8, 4-14-75; Ord. No. 1860, § 4, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 2238, § 1, 12-5-02; Ord. No. 2263 § 1, 5-24-04)  
Sec. 2.73. - SUBDIVISION OF CONTRACT OR PURCHASE PROHIBITED: 
No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 11)  
Sec. 2.74. - IMPROVEMENT ORDINANCE OR STATE IMPROVEMENT ACT TO REGULATE BIDDING FOR PUBLIC WORK, ETC., CONSTRUCTED THEREUNDER: 
Whenever any public work or improvement is to be constructed pursuant to any improvement ordinance or State Improvement Act, bidding procedures provided for therein shall control over any inconsistent provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 12)  
Sec. 2.75. - POWER OF CITY COUNCIL TO CONTRACT FOR PERSONAL SERVICES WITHOUT OBSERVING PRECEDING PROVISIONS: 
Notwithstanding any provision in this Article to the contrary, the City Council may contract for personal services, including expert personal services of an engineering, appraisal, right-of-way acquisition, legal or similar nature, without advertisement and without observing the procedure prescribed herein for the awarding of written contracts. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 13)  
Sec. 2.76. - GROUNDS AND PROCEDURE FOR SUSPENSION OF ARTICLE REQUIREMENTS: 
The requirements of this Article relating to the purchase of materials, equipment and supplies may be suspended by motion of the City Council in any case where the Council finds that strict compliance would not serve the public interest, including, but not limited to, instances where the only material, equipment or supplies that are suitable are of a unique nature and available from a single source only, where it is necessary to supplement, or acquire parts for, previously purchased equipment available from a single source only or where it is found necessary to modify an order for materials, equipment and supplies after the award of bid but prior to the completion of delivery. Such motion shall be made only on the affirmative votes of at least five (5) members of the Council. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 14)  
Sec. 2.77. - PROCEDURE FOR CONTRACTS OF SIXTY THOUSAND DOLLARS OR LESS FOR MATERIALS, EQUIPMENT, SUPPLIES OR PERSONAL SERVICES: 
The City Manager may, without public advertisement or observing the procedures prescribed herein for the awarding of written contracts, may enter into all contracts for: 
A.  All purchases of materials, equipment or supplies for sixty thousand dollars ($60,000) or less, exclusive of sales tax and freight; or 
B.  All personal service agreements for sixty thousand dollars ($60,000) or less. 
The City Manager may, if necessary funds to provide for the material, equipment or supplies required have been appropriated, issue and execute purchase orders therefore specifying the quantity, type and price of materials, equipment or supplies to be obtained and the terms and conditions of purchase, performance and delivery. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 15; Ord. No. 1340, § 1; Ord. No. 1627, § 9, 4-14-75; Ord. No. 1860, § 5, 6-14-82; Ord. No. 2238, § 1, 12-5-02; Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 5-24-04)  
Sec. 2.78. - CITY MANAGER TO ESTABLISH RULES AND MAINTAIN NECESSARY FORMS TO ADMINISTER ARTICLE: 
The City Manager may establish rules and regulations and shall prescribe and maintain such forms as he finds necessary to administer the provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 1081, § 16)  
Sec. 2.79. - CITY MANAGER AUTHORIZED TO CONTRACT FOR FORMATION, ETC., OF LOCAL ASSESSMENT DISTRICTS: 
A.  The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to contract for expert personal services of engineering, appraisal, right-of-way acquisition, and legal nature, to the extent that such services are necessary or convenient to the formation and completion of such local special assessment districts as are authorized to be instituted by the Council of the City and to the extent that unencumbered funds are available therefor. 
B.  The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to acquire property necessary or convenient for the completion of public works and improvements within such local public assessment districts as are authorized to be instituted by the Council of the City, and to the extent that unencumbered funds are available therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1340, § 2)  
Sec. 2.80. - OPEN MARKET PURCHASES: 
Any contract involving expenditures of public funds for materials, equipment, supplies or professional services, even though not required to be let by competitive bidding after publication of notice, shall nevertheless be entered into after review of such alternative sources as may be available in competition with one another and selection therefrom on the basis of obtaining maximum quality, services or performance at minimum costs. Purchases may be made in the open market without observing the bidding requirements prescribed by this Article as follows: 
A.  Purchase of personal services, supplies, materials and equipment, the expenditure for which does not exceed sixty thousand dollars ($60,000) excluding sales tax and freight. 
B.  Purchases from vendors whose names are on current established lists and have been awarded the same type of purchase contract by a state agency, county, city or other public agency after competitive bidding processes substantially equivalent to that prescribed by the City Charter or this Article; and 
C.  Such purchases conform to the specifications thereof of the City; and 
D.  The estimated price of any such purchase equal to or is lower than that estimated for such purchase if made directly by the City pursuant to the competitive bidding requirements of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 1949, § 1, 5-4-87; Ord. No. 2238, § 1, 12-5-02; Ord. No. 2263, § 1, 5-24-04)  
Secs. 2.81—2.84. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VIII. - PETITIONS 
 
Sec. 2.85. - PURPOSE OF ARTICLE: 
It is the purpose of this Article to provide implementation to Section 6 of the Charter of the City relating to the circulation or depositing of petitions for initiative, referendum or recall. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.86. - PETITIONS FOR INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM OR RECALL—CIRCULATION: 
Petitions for exercising the initiative, referendum or recall may be circulated throughout the City by the circulators for the proponents or may be deposited for signatures in at least three (3) public places in the City. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.87. - PETITIONS FOR INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM OR RECALL—ESTABLISHMENT OF DEPOSITORIES: 
The procedure for the establishment of petition depositories shall be as follows: 
A.  Any person wishing to deposit for signature any initiative, referendum or recall petition may apply to the City Council to have three (3) or more public places designated as depositories. 
B.  The application shall be in writing, and shall be filed with the City Clerk. The designation of at least three (3) depositories shall be made by the Council at its next regular meeting, provided that the Council may continue the matter to the next succeeding meeting if the application is filed less than forty-eight (48) hours before a regular Council meeting. 
C.  It shall be the obligation of the proponents to furnish a sufficient number of petitions and affidavits and chairs, tables and other necessary equipment at each depository. It shall also be the obligation of the proponents to furnish a person at each depository who has the qualifications of a circulator as established by the general law or, in the alternative, the City shall furnish such person upon payment, in advance, of the salary of such person as determined by the City Clerk. Depositories staffed by the City shall be open during the hours fixed by Section 2.9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.88. - PETITIONS FOR INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM OR RECALL—NOTICE OF DEPOSIT: 
Notice of the deposit of a petition shall be given by and at the expense of the proponents in accordance with Section 6 of the Charter in the same newspaper utilized by the City for the publication of ordinances and in such additional newspapers as may be deemed advisable by the proponents. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.89. - PETITIONS FOR INITIATIVE, REFERENDUM OR RECALL—DESIGNATION OF DEPOSITORIES NOT TO CONSTITUTE COUNCIL ENDORSEMENT: 
The designation of depositories pursuant to the foregoing procedure shall in no manner constitute an endorsement or approval of any measure or proposal by the Council nor shall such designation indicate approval of the form of any petition. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.90. - APPLICABILITY OF ARTICLE: 
The provisions of this Article shall be applicable to recall proceedings under Section 47c of the Charter and to referendum proceedings under Section 48a of the Charter as well as for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of Section 6 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.91. - REFERENDUM ON LEASES APPROVED BY BOARD OF PORT COMMISSIONERS: 
Leases approved by the Board of Port Commissioners shall be subject to referendum from the date of the action of the Board approving the lease for a period of thirty (30) days or until the lease is awarded, whichever is later in time. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Sec. 2.92. - APPLICABILITY OF STATE LAW: 
Except as provided otherwise by the Charter of the City and this Code, the general laws of the State applicable to municipalities shall be applicable to the circulating of petitions for the initiative, referendum and recall and to the examination of such petitions and all proceedings thereunder. 
Any initiative, referendum or recall proceedings relating to a district formed by the City shall, except as provided otherwise by any ordinance of the City, be conducted pursuant to the general laws of the State applicable to districts. 
(Ord. No. 1255, § 1)  
Secs. 2.93—2.99. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE IX. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2.100. - APPLICABILITY OF ARTICLE: 
The organization of, and the duties and functions of, all boards and commissions established pursuant to Section 21 ½ of the Charter of the City shall be as prescribed in this Article, provided that the Council may, from time to time, prescribe such additional duties and functions by ordinance or resolution as it may deem appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1288, § 2)  
Sec. 2.101. - RULES OF OPERATION: 
Except as specifically provided otherwise, the following rules shall apply to the operation of all boards and commissions: 
A.  A majority of the commission shall constitute a quorum. 
B.  Action shall be taken only on the affirmative vote of a majority of the members present at a duly constituted meeting. 
C.  The time and place of the regular meetings of every board and commission shall be established by resolution of that board or commission. 
D.  Each board and commission may adopt such procedural rules and regulations as may be necessary or convenient for the orderly conduct of its business. 
E.  The provisions of section 54950 et seq., of the Government Code relating to the conduct of regular, adjourned and special meetings shall be applicable to all boards and commissions. 
F.  All members of any board or commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 1288, § 2)  
Sec. 2.102. - VACANCIES; REMOVAL OF MEMBERS: 
In the case of a vacancy in a board or commission for any cause, a successor shall be appointed by the Council for the unexpired term. 
Any member of any board or commission may be removed at any time by the affirmative vote of five-sevenths ( 5/7 ) of the members of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 1288, § 2)  
Sec. 2.103. - CHARTER PROVISIONS: 
Reference is made to the following Charter provisions establishing specific boards and commissions. 
A.  Section 17, Planning Commission. 
B.  Section 18, Library Board. 
C.  Section 47a, Board of Port Commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1288, § 2)  
Sec. 2.104. - DESIGNATED: 
Reference is made to the following boards and commissions established by this Code or by other action of the Council: 
A.  Section 2.110, et seq., Arts Commission. 
B.  Section 2.120, et seq., Board of Building Review. 
C.  Section 23.13, et seq., Personnel Board. 
D.  Section 25.3.01, et seq., Parks, Recreation, and Community Services Commission. 
E.  Ordinance No. 1130, Architectural Committee. 
(Ord. No. 1288, § 2; Ord. No. 1494, § 1, 6-14-71; Ord. No. 2307, § 1, 5-7-07; Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Secs. 2.105—2.109. - RESERVED:  
DIVISION 2. - ARTS COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), adopted May 6, 2019, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 2.110—2.119, pertained to Civic Cultural Commission, and derived from Ord. No. 1494, § 3, adopted June 14, 1971; Ord. No. 1603, § 1, adopted June 10, 1974; Ord. No. 1785, § 1, adopted June 4, 1979; Ord. No. 1950, § 1, adopted July 6, 1987; Ord. No. 2121, § 1, adopted Jan. 6, 1997; and Ord. No. 2273, § 1, adopted Sept. 27, 2004. 
 
Sec. 2.110. - ESTABLISHED; GENERAL OBJECTIVES: 
There is hereby established an Arts Commission. The general objectives of the Arts Commission shall be to ensure that art, culture, and creative experiences are woven into the fabric of the community, and to encourage, foster, facilitate, establish, and maintain art and programs for all matters of artistic and cultural significance in the City. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.111. - COMPOSITION; QUALIFICATIONS OF MEMBERS: 
The Arts Commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the City Council. All such members shall be persons who have demonstrated a deep interest in and appreciation of artistic and cultural matters. At least four (4) such members shall be persons active in and representative of one (1) or more of the following fields: architecture, art, design, video/film, literary arts, marketing/advertising, music, public relations, theater, or visual arts. All such members shall, at the time of their appointment and continuously during their incumbency, be residents of the City. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.112. - TERMS OF MEMBERS: 
The term of office of each member of the Arts Commission shall be four (4) years, expiring on May 31 of the fourth year; provided, however, that appointments to the Arts Commission shall be made such that terms shall expire in even-numbered years. Members shall continue to serve until their respective successors are appointed and qualified. 
No member shall be eligible for appointment to more than four (4) consecutive full terms of office; but any former member shall be eligible for appointment to the Arts Commission two (2) years after that member ceased serving on the Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.113. - POWERS AND DUTIES: 
To achieve the general objectives of the Arts Commission, its powers and duties shall be as follows: 
A.  To review and make recommendations to the Council or Manager concerning the acquisition by the City of any work of art, or item of cultural significance, and the proposed location thereof. 
B.  To review and make recommendations to the Council or Manager for the establishment or termination of visual and performing art programs in the City. 
C.  To review and make recommendations to the Council or Manager for the allocation of City funds for arts and culture in the City. 
D.  To review and make recommendations to the Council or Manager for the establishment or termination of programs memorializing or giving recognition to matters of cultural significance in the City. 
E.  To review and make recommendations to the Council or Manager concerning the removal, relocation, maintenance, or alteration of existing works of art or items of cultural significance in the possession of the City. 
F.  Upon request, to advise the Council and other City boards or commissions regarding any matter affecting the beauty and culture of the City. 
G.  To review and make recommendations to the Council or Manager concerning public art in accordance with the duties established in City Code Chapter 45 (Public Art). 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.113.5. - DEFINITIONS: 
As used in this Division: 
PROGRAMS: "Programs" shall mean comprehensive and planned activities or functions including, but not necessarily limited to, the following: concerts, plays, festivals, art shows and exhibits, contests, seminars, lectures, workshops and classes, whether conducted individually or in a series; the construction and maintenance of museums, galleries, theaters, and other buildings or structures generally associated with works of art, the performing and visual arts, or matters of cultural significance; and the making of awards or otherwise giving recognition to achievements of participants in such programs. 
WORKS OF ART: "Works of Art" shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, all murals, paintings, inscriptions, reliefs, statues, sculptures, monuments, installations, or other structures intended for commemorative, artistic, or aesthetic purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.114. - REFERRAL OF CULTURAL MATTERS, ETC. TO COMMISSION FOR REVIEW AND RECOMMENDATION: 
All matters pertaining to works of art or programs regarding the performing and visual arts and matters of cultural significance, and similar matters coming before the Council or Manager shall be referred by them to the Arts Commission for its review and recommendations. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.115. - SERVICES OF DEPARTMENT HEADS: 
The Arts Commission may require the services of the City Manager, Planning Director, City Attorney, and such other department heads as the Commission deems necessary to furnish technical or professional advice and services, subject to the prior engagement of such officers in other public duties. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.116. - OFFICERS—ENUMERATED; ELECTION: 
The officers of the Arts Commission shall be a Chair and a Vice Chair, each of whom shall serve for a period of one (1) year. Yearly elections shall be held by the Commission to elect such officers. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.117. - OFFICERS—DUTIES: 
The duties of the officers of the Arts Commission shall be as follows: 
A.  Chair. The Chair shall help City staff prepare the agenda, preside at all meetings, ensure that all commissioners' voices are heard, be the public voice of the Commission, and in general do all things ordinarily required of a commission chair. 
B.  Vice-Chair. The Vice-Chair shall assume and perform the duties of the Chair in the Chair's absence. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.118. - APPOINTMENT OF COMMITTEES; FUNCTION, REPORTS OF COMMITTEES: 
From time to time the Arts Commission may appoint committees, the membership of which shall be composed of a commissioner, as chairman, and such other persons, either members of the Commission or otherwise, who may be selected by the Commission. Such committees shall function in investigations and in providing information and data necessary for the establishment of programs to be recommended by the Commission. After the completion of the work of such a committee, it shall submit a written report including recommendations to the Commission relating to its work. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
Sec. 2.119. - APPROPRIATIONS, USES OF CITY PROPERTY: 
The Council shall make such annual appropriations, and allow the use of such City property, real and personal, as the Council may deem necessary for the purpose of carrying on the activities of the Arts Commission. 
(Ord. No. 2459, § 4(Exh. A), 5-6-19)  
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF BUILDING REVIEW 
 
Sec. 2.120. - ESTABLISHED, MEMBERSHIP: 
There is hereby established a City Board of Building Review which shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the Council who are qualified by experience and training in the building construction fields. 
(Ord. No. 1381, § 10, 12-16-1968)  
Sec. 2.121. - TERMS OF MEMBERS: 
The term of office of each member of the Board of Building Review shall be four (4) years, expiring on May 31 of the fourth year; provided, however, that appointments to the Board shall be made such that terms shall expire in even-numbered years. 
(Ord. No. 1381, § 10, 12-16-1968; Ord. No. 2121, § 2, 1-6-1997)  
Sec. 2.122. - SELECTION OF CHAIRMAN; DESIGNATION, DUTIES OF SECRETARY: 
The Board shall annually elect one of its members to be chairman. The Building Inspector shall be the secretary to the Board, shall keep permanent accurate records of all proceedings before the Board and shall perform such administrative functions as may be specified by the Board. 
(Ord. No. 1381, § 10, 12-16-1968)  
Sec. 2.123. - GENERAL DUTY, RESPONSIBILITY, POWER OF BOARD: 
Whenever any provision of Chapter 9 of this Code (including the codes adopted therein by reference) prescribes or delegates any duty, responsibility or power upon a board of appeals or board of review, the Board of Building Review shall have such duty, responsibility or power. Such authority shall not extend to appeal provisions of codes adopted by reference when such appeal provisions are expressly not adopted. 
(Ord. No. 1381, § 10, 12-16-1968)  
Sec. 2.124. - RECOMMENDATION OF AMENDMENTS TO CODES ADOPTED IN CHAPTER 9: 
The Board of Building Review may recommend amendments to the Council for any of the codes adopted by Chapter 9 of this Code.
