ARTICLE V. - PEDESTRIANS' RIGHTS AND DUTIES 
 
Sec. 20.48. - ESTABLISHMENT AND DESIGNATION OF CROSSWALKS: 
The City Manager shall establish, designate and maintain crosswalks at intersections and other places by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway as follows: 
A.  Crosswalks shall be established and maintained at all intersections where the City Manager determines that there is a particular hazard to pedestrians crossing the roadway subject to the limitations contained in subsection B of this Section. 
B.  Other than crosswalks at intersections, no crosswalk shall be established in any block which is less than four hundred feet (400') in length. Elsewhere, not more than one additional crosswalk shall be established in any one block, and such crosswalk shall be located as nearly as practicable at mid-block. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 110; Ord. No. 1280, § 1) 
State Law reference— Power of local authorities to establish crosswalks, § 21106.  
Sec. 20.49. - WHEN PEDESTRIAN MUST USE CROSSWALKS: 
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than by a crosswalk in any business district. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 111)  
Sec. 20.50. - CROSSING ROADWAY AT RIGHT ANGLES: 
No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb except in a marked crosswalk. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 112)  
Sec. 20.51. - STANDING IN ROADWAYS; APPLICATION OF SECTION: 
No person shall stand in any roadway other than in a safety zone or in a crosswalk if such action interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. This provision shall not apply to any public officer or employee, or employee of a public utility when necessarily upon a street in line of duty. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 113)  
ARTICLE VI. - TRUCK TRAFFIC ROUTES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Size, weight and load of vehicles generally, Veh. C., §§ 35000—35793; powers of local authorities as to size, weight and load of vehicles generally, Veh. C., §§ 35700—35714; establishment of weight limitations on bridges. etc., Veh. C., §§ 35750—35754. 
 
DIVISION I. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 20.52. - DESIGNATED: 
The following streets are hereby declared to be truck traffic routes for the movement of vehicles exceeding a maximum gross weight of three (3) tons, hereinafter called "trucks", and the City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to designate such streets by appropriate signs as "truck route". The streets are specifically designated as follows: 
Bay Road from Chestnut Street to Second Avenue. 
Bayshore Highway within the City. 
Broadway from Chestnut Street to Fifth Avenue. 
Charter Street from Spring Street to Bayshore Highway. 
Chestnut Street between El Camino Real and Bayshore Highway. 
Douglas Avenue between Bay Road and Broadway and all of Douglas Avenue northerly from Broadway. 
El Camino Real within the City. 
Fifth Avenue between Broadway and Bayshore Highway. 
Harbor Boulevard within the City. 
Industrial Way within the City. 
Jefferson Avenue between El Camino Real and Pennsylvania Avenue. 
Main Street within the City. 
Maple Street between El Camino Real and Main Street. 
Middlefield Road southerly of Main Street. 
Pennsylvania Avenue between Jefferson Avenue and Monroe Street. 
Second Avenue from Bay Road to Broadway. 
Spring Street between Chestnut Street and Douglas Avenue. 
Spruce Street within the City. 
Stafford Street within the City. 
Whipple Avenue between El Camino Real and Bayshore Highway. 
Woodside Road, within the City. 
(Ord. No. 781; Ord. No. 790)  
Sec. 20.53. - USE BY VEHICLES EXCEEDING THREE TONS REQUIRED GENERALLY: 
No person shall operate any truck having a gross weight in excess of three (3) tons on any street in the City except on those streets specified in the preceding section and subject to the exceptions provided in Sections 20.55 to 20.58 and 20.61. 
(Ord. No. 781) 
State Law reference— Provisions authorizing local authorities to prohibit use of street by commercial vehicle exceeding specified weight, Veh. C., § 35701.  
Sec. 20.54. - USE BY TRUCKS HAVING OUTSIDE CITY ORIGIN—DESTINATION OUTSIDE CITY: 
All trucks entering the City for a destination point outside the City shall operate only over a truck route as established by Section 20.52. 
(Ord. No. 781)  
Sec. 20.55. - USE BY TRUCKS HAVING OUTSIDE CITY ORIGIN—ONE INSIDE CITY DESTINATION: 
All trucks entering the City for a destination point in the City shall enter the City only on an established truck route as set out in Section 20.52 and shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point the deviating truck shall return to the nearest truck route by the shortest route. 
(Ord. No. 781) 
State Law reference— Requirement that local ordinance not interfere with pick-up or delivery of goods, etc., by commercial vehicles on restricted streets, Veh. C., § 35703.  
Sec. 20.56. - USE BY TRUCKS HAVING OUTSIDE CITY ORIGIN—MULTIPLE INSIDE CITY DESTINATIONS: 
All trucks entering the City for multiple destination points shall enter the City only on established truck routes as set out in Section 20.52, shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to all other destination points by the shortest route. Upon leaving the last destination point the deviating truck shall return to the nearest truck route by the shortest route. 
(Ord. No. 781) 
State Law reference— Requirement that local ordinance not interfere with pick-up or delivery of goods, etc., by commercial vehicles on restricted streets, Veh. C., § 35703.  
Sec. 20.57. - USE BY TRUCKS HAVING INSIDE CITY ORIGIN—DESTINATION OUTSIDE CITY: 
All trucks on a trip originating in the City and traveling in the City for a destination point outside the City shall proceed by the shortest route to the nearest truck route as established by Section 20.52. 
(Ord. No. 781) 
State Law reference— Requirement that local ordinance not interfere with pick-up or delivery of goods, etc., by commercial vehicles on restricted streets, Veh. C., § 35703.  
Sec. 20.58. - USE BY TRUCKS HAVING INSIDE CITY ORIGIN—DESTINATION INSIDE CITY: 
All trucks on a trip originating in the City and traveling in the City for destination points in the City shall proceed to such destination points by the shortest route. 
(Ord. No. 781) 
State Law reference— Requirement that local ordinance not interfere with pick-up or delivery of goods, etc., by commercial vehicles on restricted streets. Veh. C., § 35703.  
Sec. 20.59. - AUTHORITY TO REQUIRE WEIGHING: 
Any police officer shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any truck on any public street or highway in the City to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining whether this Article has been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 781)  
Sec. 20.60. - EFFECT OF ARTICLE ON STATE HIGHWAYS: 
This Article shall cease to be effective as to any State highways within six (6) months after the receipt of notice from the Department of Public Works of the State of the withdrawal of its consent to the establishment of any restrictions affecting State highways herein. 
(Ord. No. 781) 
State Law reference— Requirement that local ordinances as to weight requirements for commercial vehicles on State highways, etc., be submitted to Department of Public Works for approval, Veh. C., § 35702.  
Sec. 20.61. - EXCEPTIONS TO APPLICATION OF ARTICLE: 
Nothing in this Article shall be construed as applying to any truck coming from an unrestricted street having ingress and egress by direct route to and from streets on which truck traffic is restricted as herein provided when necessary for the purpose of making pickups or deliveries of goods, wares and merchandise from or to any building or structure located on streets other than truck routes or for the purpose of delivering materials to be used in the actual and bona fide repair, alteration, remodeling or construction of any building or structure upon a street other than a truck route for which a building permit has previously been obtained, or to any vehicle owned by a public utility while necessarily in use in the construction, installation or repair of any public utility, or to any vehicle which is subject to the provisions of sections 1031 to 1036, inclusive, of the Public Utilities Code of the State, or to any vehicle owned or operated by the City while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 105(F); Ord. No. 781; Ord. No. 998, § 29) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Veh. C., §§ 35703, 35704.  
DIVISION 2. - LIMITED USE OF STREETS BY PERMIT; FEES:[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1866, §§ 1, 2, enacted Sept. 20, 1982, repealed Div. 2, §§ 20.62—20.82, pertaining to limited truck traffic routes, and enacted in lieu thereof a new Div. 2, §§ 20.62—20.74, as herein set out. Former Div. 2 was derived from Ord. No. 920, § 1. 
Cross reference— Uses of Rights-of-Way, Ch. 33A. 
 
Sec. 20.62. - PURPOSE: 
The purpose of this Division is to regulate earth hauling on City streets, as a result of grading, excavating or fill operations, or combinations thereof; and further, to establish user fees for earth hauling, which has been found to be the single most significant contributor to the premature deterioration of streets within the City, the proceeds of which will be designated for repair and maintenance of those streets actually used for such earth-hauling activity. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82; Ord. No. 1878, § 1, 9-19-83)  
Sec. 20.63. - "EARTH HAULING" DEFINED: 
For the purpose of this Division, "earth hauling" shall be defined as the transportation, on and upon City streets, of any material resulting from or to be used in grading, excavating or fill operations, or combinations thereof, excepting therefrom aggregate base and asphalt concrete materials used for roadway and parking area structural sections to be placed above the subgrade plane. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82; Ord. No. 1878, § 2, 9-19-83)  
Sec. 20.64. - USE BY VEHICLES HAULING EARTH MATERIAL EXCEEDING THREE TONS: 
Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, vehicle hauling earth material the gross weight, including load, of which exceeds three (3) tons, may be permitted along streets from which they are otherwise excluded. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.65. - APPLICATION FOR PERMIT: 
Any person desiring to haul earth materials exceeding three (3) tons, within the City, except on a truck route as so designated in Section 20.52 of this Code, shall file an application in triplicate for a permit to do so with the Director of Public Works, the original of which shall be verified. The application shall set forth the following information: 
A.  A full identification, and the residence and business address of the applicant, including all members of any firm or partnership, and the president and secretary of any corporation applying; if the applicant is the agent or employee of any person for whose benefit the permit is requested, this fact, with the full identification of such person and his business and residence address. 
B.  The facts constituting the necessity for the hauling. 
C.  The amount of material expected to be hauled, in tons. 
D.  The dates on which the hauling is intended to be commenced and completed, and the times of day during which hauling is intended to be done. 
E.  The particular streets over which a permit to operate is requested. 
F.  The time interval between vehicles and the number of vehicles per hour, which will travel over the route for which the permit is applied. 
G.  The location of the place or places of delivery of the materials, provided, however, that if delivery is to be made in small quantities to numerous places, a general description satisfactory to the Director of Public Works of the locations of the contemplated deliveries will be sufficient. 
H.  A specific description of the vehicle or vehicles and load to be operated or moved. 
I.  Whether such permit is requested for a single trip or for continuous operation. 
J.  Such further information as the Director of Public Works may require. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.65.1. - PERMIT FEE: 
A.  As a condition to the issuance of a permit, the permittee shall pay to the City at the office of the Director of Community Development a fee for the privilege of said permit in an amount hereinafter specified, which amount shall be considered as a liquidated sum in compensation for and in full satisfaction of all damages and injury to those routes specified in said permit. It is found upon investigation that payment of said sum is necessary to protect said street(s) from the actual damages and injury which will occur as a result of such hauling, and that said sum will provide full indemnity for the damages and injury resulting from such hauling; and by reason of the difficulty in computing such damages, the hereinafter specified amount is found in advance to be reasonable compensation for the use of said street(s) as a condition of such hauling. The Director of Community Development is authorized to accept said sum in full satisfaction for all damages and injury to said street(s) to be caused by such hauling. 
B.  The fee for the privilege granted by said permit shall be in an amount set by resolution of the City Council. 
C.  If the amount of earth proposed to be hauled cannot be measured in cubic yards, measurement may be made by weight using the conversion factor hereinafter set forth. For the purposes of the division, one cubic foot of earth material shall be equivalent to one hundred twenty-five (125) pounds; provided, however, that if an applicant submits to the Director of Community Development evidence that such factor of equivalency is not accurate with respect to a certain proposed load, the Director may, in his or her discretion, utilize a different equivalent for the purposes of computing the fee. 
D.  No application for a permit to haul earth shall be subdivided to avoid payment of a fee or any other requirements of this Division. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82; Ord. No. 2025, § 1, 7-23-90; Ord. No. 2436, § 5, 5-22-17)  
Sec. 20.66. - PAYMENT OF FEE: 
A.  The Director of Public Works shall require, as a condition to granting of any permit hereunder that the applicant, prior to the issuance of the permit, deposit with the Director of Public Works, as security for the payment of fees specified in Section 20.65, a sum of money to be fixed by the Director of Public Works, which sum shall be calculated based upon the estimated amount of earth to be hauled during the first month (or other shorter period) of the duration of the permit, in accordance with the permit fee schedule set forth in Section 20.65. 
B.  If the permit is for hauling of more than a month's duration, payment of the permit fee may be made monthly, in advance, in amounts based upon the estimated amount of earth to be hauled in the following month. 
C.  If, upon completion of any month's hauling under said permit, the total fee payable is determined to be greater than the amount actually paid, the amount still owing shall be added to the charge for the next estimated monthly installment. Upon completion of all hauling under said permit the permittee shall pay to the City, at the office of the Director of Public Works, any amount still owing, within thirty (30) days from the date of completion. 
D.  If, at the end of any month's hauling under said permit, the total fee payable is determined to be less than the amount actually paid, the amount of overpayment shall be subtracted from the charge for the next estimated monthly installment. Upon completion of all hauling under said permit, the City shall refund the amount of any overpayment of the permittee within thirty (30) days from receipt by the Director of Public Works of a documented request therefor. 
E.  Any amount deposited pursuant to this Section shall be returned, (less the sum of $30.00 to cover the cost of processing the application) to an applicant if, prior to the commencement of any hauling operation pursuant to such application, applicant shall have notified the Director of Public Works of intention not to engage in such hauling operation and requested return of said deposit. 
F.  All notices required by this Section shall be in writing and delivered personally to the Director of Public Works or transmitted prepaid by United States registered or certified mail, and addressed to him at City Hall, Box 391, Redwood City, California. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.67. - DEPOSIT OF FEES INTO GAS TAX FUND: 
The fees collected pursuant to this Division shall be deposited into the "Special Gas Tax Street Improvement Fund" of the City as established by Section 2.41.3 of this Code, and shall be designated, to the extent reasonably practicable, for repair and maintenance of those streets on which the hauling, for which the fees were collected, took place. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.68. - ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; DESIGNATION OF ROUTES: 
A.  The Director of Public Works shall issue a permit pursuant to this Division upon acceptance of a completed application and upon payment of the required fee therefor, and upon the determination by the Director that the hauling operation for which Such permit is requested reasonably requires the use of City streets other than truck routes as designated in Section 20.52 of this Code. The permit shall be subject to such reasonable conditions as the Director deems necessary to protect the public health and safety. 
B.  The Director of Public Works shall establish, and the permit shall specify the route or routes over which all vehicles subject to the permit shall travel, and such vehicles shall travel only directly over such route, or routes, as the Director of Public Works determines to be the least dangerous to public safety, and which shall cause the least interference with general traffic and the least damage to public streets. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.69. - CONDITIONS OF PERMIT: 
The Director of Public Works shall determine, and the permit shall specify, the conditions of use, including, but not limited to, the following: 
A.  The gross weight limit of each truck or vehicle which shall be authorized to haul under the permit. 
B.  The time interval between vehicles, and the number of trucks per hour which shall be permitted to travel over the route specified. 
C.  The hours of the day and the days of the week during which such trucks shall be permitted to travel over the route. 
D.  The total number of yards of material which may be hauled subject to the permit. 
E.  The period during which the permit is effective. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.70. - DISPLAY OF PERMIT: 
Every permit issued hereunder shall be carried in the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection of any peace officer of traffic officer, any authorized agent of the Department of Public Works or any other officer or employee charged with the care or protection of the City's streets. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.71. - APPEALS: 
In the event an applicant for a permit hereunder disputes the determination of the Director of Public Works with respect to the conditions attached to a permit, including the designated routes to be traveled under the permit, or the amount of the fee, the applicant may appeal such determination to the City Manager in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 1 of this Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82) 
(Ord. No. 2374, § 12, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 20.72. - EVIDENCE ON APPEAL: 
At the time set for hearing the City Council may summon witnesses and hear evidence relating to the application. The Council may continue the hearing from time to time. At the conclusion thereof, the Council shall make its finding thereon and may uphold or overrule the determination of the Director of Public Works or make such modifications thereto, as it may deem fit. The findings and order of the Council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.73. - APPLICATION OF DIVISION: 
Except as specifically stated in this Division, nothing in this Division or in any permit granted under this Division shall be deemed to authorize the doing or omission of any act contrary to any term or provision of this Chapter or any ordinance or license of this City or without any license or permit otherwise required by such term, provision, ordinance or license. The provisions of this Division shall not be deemed to establish any street or highway or portion thereof as a "truck route" as that phrase is used in Sections 20.52 to 20.61. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
Sec. 20.74. - HAULING WITHOUT PERMIT; VIOLATING TERMS OF PERMIT: 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul earth on any City street except a truck route as so designated in Section 20.52 of this Code, without having obtained the permit required by this Division, or to violate any of the terms and conditions of a permit issued pursuant to this Division. 
(Ord. No. 1866, § 2, 9-20-82)  
DIVISION 3. - INTERSTATE TRUCK ACCESS 
 
Sec. 20.75. - DEFINITIONS: 
The following words and phrases shall for the purpose of the Sections 20.75.1 to 20.75.7 have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this Section. 
Whenever any words or phrases used in these sections are not defined herein, but are now defined in the California Vehicle Code, such definitions are incorporated herein and shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used herein as though set forth in this Chapter in full. 
CALTRANS: Means the State of California Department of Transportation or its successor agency or agencies. 
INTERSTATE TRUCK: Means a truck tractor and semitrailer or truck tractor, semitrailer and trailer with unlimited length as regulated by California Vehicle Code, particularly Vehicle Code section 35401.5(a)(1) and (2). 
TERMINAL: Means any facility at which freight is consolidated to be shipped or where full load consignments may be loaded and off loaded or at which the vehicles are regularly maintained, stored, or manufactured. 
TRAFFIC ENGINEER or ENGINEER: Means the traffic engineer of the City of Redwood City or his/her authorized representative. 
TRAIL BLAZER SIGNS: Means interstate truck route identification signs to and from terminals. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Sec. 20.75.1. - PURPOSE: 
The purpose and intent of this Division is to regulate and establish procedures for terminal designation and truck route designation to terminals for interstate trucks operating on a federally designated highway system and to promote the general health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Sec. 20.75.2. - APPLICATION PROCESS: 
A.  A person who has an ownership interest in a terminal and requiring terminal access for interstate trucks from a federally designated highway system shall submit an application, on a form as provided by the Department of Public Works, together with such other information as may be required by the Traffic Engineer and the appropriate fees to the City. 
B.  Upon receipt of the application and payment of the fee, the Traffic Engineer will initiate an investigation to determine the applicant's conformance with interstate truck terminal requirements. Upon the Engineer's approval that the applicant has fulfilled all requirements of an interstate truck terminal, the Engineer will then determine the capability of the route requested and alternate routes, whether requested or not. 
C.  Should the requested route through the City be to a terminal located in another jurisdiction, the applicant shall comply with that jurisdiction's application process. Coordination of the approval of the route through the City will be the responsibility of the jurisdiction which controls the terminal's land use. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Sec. 20.75.3. - FEES: 
A.  The applicant shall pay a nonrefundable application fee, as established by the City by resolution, sufficient to pay the cost of the review of the terminal designation and the review of the route and alternative route. 
B.  Upon the approval of the terminal designation and route by the City and by Caltrans, the applicant shall deposit with the City sufficient funds as estimated by the Traffic Engineer to pay for the purchase and installation of terminal trail blazer signs. Trail blazer signs will be required at every decision point in the City on route to the terminal. On completion of the installation of the signs, the actual cost shall be computed and the difference between the actual and estimated cost shall be billed or refunded to the applicant, whichever the case may be. No terminal or route may be used until such signs as may be required are in place. Cost for trail blazer signs may be proportioned in accordance with procedures in Section 20.75.4C. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Sec. 20.75.4. - RETROFITTING: 
A.  If all feasible routes to a requested terminal are deemed unsatisfactory by the Traffic Engineer, the applicant may request retrofitting deficiencies in the physical condition of a route acceptable to the Engineer. All costs of engineering, construction and inspection therefor shall be borne by the applicant. 
B.  The applicant shall, at its own cost and expense, construct all of the retrofitting improvements, furnish all the materials, and do all the work necessary to complete the retrofitting. Before approval of the route, the applicant shall furnish to the City and file with the City Clerk a bond, deposit or instrument of credit securing the faithful performance of applicant of all work and the construction of all retrofitting required for the approval of such route. The applicant shall also deposit with the City a sum for all engineering, inspections, plan check, laboratory and field testing, construction, and other services furnished by the City in connection with the retrofitting improvements. Adjustments between the estimated and actual cost shall be made after completion of the work and any difference between the actual and the estimated cost shall be billed or refunded to the applicant, as the case may be. When the work is done by the applicant, the applicant may file with the Traffic Engineer, on a form satisfactory to the Traffic Engineer, a statement detailing the actual cost of the retrofitting. 
C.  If at any time within three (3) years, from the date of completion, or City's acceptance, of the retrofitting constructed by the applicant, should any other applicant seek terminal approval which would use the route upon which such retrofitting was accomplished, any such later applicant's fee may include that applicant's proportionate share of the retrofitting, as determined by the Traffic Engineer, which fee shall be disbursed by the City to the applicant who paid for the retrofitting as well as to any other applicant who may have contributed to the costs of retrofitting under this subdivision. Nothing herein shall require the pay ment of a proportionate fee if the applicant doing the work failed to file the report with the Traffic Engineer required by subdivision B above. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Sec. 20.75.5. - REVOCATION OF ROUTE: 
The Director of Public Works is authorized to revoke any approved route if said route proves to be a safety hazard for any vehicular traffic. A safety hazard shall be defined as an inability of the interstate trucks safely to negotiate the route and/or said trucks cause unsafe driving conditions for other vehicular traffic and/or pedestrians, and/or cause extraordinary damage to or impair the use of any public street or other public improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Sec. 20.75.6. - APPEAL PROCESS: 
A.  If the Traffic Engineer or the Director of Public Works upon review of the Engineer's decision denies a terminal designation, disapproves a route designation, or revokes a previously approved terminal or route, the applicant/terminal owner, within fifteen (15) days following the date of the notice of the decision of the Traffic Engineer or Director of Public Works, may appeal said decision to the City Council in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 1 of this Municipal Code. 
B.  If Caltrans and not the Traffic Engineer, denies or revokes terminal access from federally designated highways, no appeal shall be made to the City Council, but shall be made to Caltrans as may be permitted by Caltrans. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85) 
(Ord. No. 2374, § 13, 1-9-12)  
Sec. 20.75.7. - SEVERABILITY: 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Division is for any reason held to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this Division, and each section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase therein. 
(Ord. No. 1907, § 1, 2-25-85)  
Secs. 20.76—20.82. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING* 
Cross reference— Parking bicycles within business district, § 8.7; parking trailers on streets, § 34.3. 
State Law reference— Power of local authorities to prohibit, etc., parking, Veh. C., § 22507; stopping, standing or parking generally, Veh. C., §§ 22500—22518; removal of parked and abandoned vehicles, Veh. C., §§ 22650—22856; also see Veh. C., § 22515. 
* Amendment note: Ord. No. 2287, § 1, enacted August 22, 2005, repealed former Division 1, §§ 20.96—20.96.32, relating to limitation of parking time on certain designated streets, derived from Ord. Nos. 758, 901, 919, 944, 957, 959, 972, 1041, 1043, 1045, 1069, 1085, 1100, 1117, 1122, 1127, 1135, 1148, 1184, 1311, 1416, 1460, 1465, 1477, 1498, 1653, 1933, 1939, 1948, 2071, 2117 and 2155. Section 1 of said Ord. No. 2287 enacted § 20.96 as herein set out.  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 20.83. - APPLICATION OF ARTICLE: 
The provisions of this Article prohibiting the stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic-control device. 
The provisions of this Article imposing a time limit on standing or parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions of the Vehicle Code of this State or the ordinances of this City, prohibiting or limiting the standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 120)  
Sec. 20.84. - MARKING OF PARKING SPACES—GENERALLY; VEHICLES TO BE PARKED WITHIN MARKED LINES: 
The City Manager is authorized to install and maintain parking space markings to indicate parking spaces adjacent to curbings where authorized parking is permitted. 
When such parking space markings are placed in the highway, subject to other and more restrictive limitations, no vehicle shall be stopped, left standing or parked other than within a single space unless the size or shape of such vehicle makes compliance impossible. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 153) 
State Law reference— Power of local authorities to mark parking spaces. Veh. C., § 22508.  
Sec. 20.85. - MARKING OF PARKING SPACES—WHERE ANGLE PARKING PERMITTED; VEHICLES TO BE PARKED WITHIN MARKED LINES: 
A.  Whenever any ordinance of this City designates and describes any street or portion thereof upon which angle parking shall be permitted, the City Manager shall mark or sign such street indicating the location and the angle at which vehicles shall be parked. 
B.  When signs or markings are in place indicating angle parking as herein provided, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the location and angle indicated by such signs or markings. 
C.  Angle parking shall be permitted upon those streets and parts of streets described in Section 20.99. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 1; Ord. No. 1443, § 1, 2-2-70) 
Amendment note— Ord. No. 1443, § 1, amended § 20.85 by rewording subsection B.  
Sec. 20.86. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES—IN PARKWAYS: 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within any parkway. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 121) 
State Law reference— Prohibition against parking in specified places, Veh. C., § 22500.  
Sec. 20.87. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN SPECIFIED PLACES—NEAR INTERSECTIONS, TRAFFIC SIGNS AND SIGNALS OR HAZARDOUS PLACES: 
The City Manager shall appropriately sign or mark the following places and where so signed or marked, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any of such places: 
A.  At any place within fifteen feet (15') of an intersection in any business district except that a bus may stop at a designated bus stop. 
B.  Within twenty-five feet (25') of the approach to any traffic signal, boulevard stop sign or official electric flashing device. 
C.  At any place where the City Manager determines that it is necessary in order to eliminate unusual traffic hazard. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 129)  
Sec. 20.88. - PARKING ADJACENT TO SCHOOLS: 
A.  The City Manager is hereby authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
B.  When official signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of a street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 126)  
Sec. 20.89. - PARKING ON NARROW STREETS: 
A.  The City Manager is hereby authorized to place signs or markings indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty feet (20'), or upon one side of a street, as indicated by such signs or markings when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty feet (30'). 
B.  When official signs or markings prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such street in violation of any such sign or marking. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 127)  
Sec. 20.90. - MANNER OF PARKING ON HILLS: 
No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle unattended on a highway when upon any grade exceeding three percent (3%) within any business or residence district without blocking the wheels of said vehicle by turning them against the curb or by other means. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 128) 
State Law reference— Local regulation of parking on hills, Veh. C., § 22509.  
Sec. 20.91. - MANNER OF PARKING ON ONE-WAY ROADWAYS: 
A.  Subject to other and more restrictive limitations, a vehicle may be stopped or parked within eighteen inches (18?) of the left-hand curb facing in the direction of traffic movement upon any one-way street unless signs are in place prohibiting such stopping or standing. 
B.  In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway unless signs are in place permitting such standing or parking. 
C.  The City Manager is authorized to determine when standing or parking shall be prohibited upon the left-hand side of any one-way street or when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any one-way roadway of a highway having two (2) or more separate roadways and shall erect signs giving notice thereof. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 124) 
State Law reference— Power of local authorities to permit left-hand parking on one-way roadways, Veh. C., § 22503.  
Sec. 20.91.4. - ENFORCEMENT OF PARKING REGULATION ON PRIVATE ROADS NOT OPEN TO PUBLIC USE: 
Pursuant to the provisions of section 21107.7 of the Vehicle Code of the State of California it is hereby found and declared that there are privately owned and maintained roads as described in this Code Section within the City that are not generally held open for use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel but by reason of their proximity to or connection with highways the interests of any residents residing along such roads will best be served by application of provisions of the Vehicle Code to these roads and, therefore, the provisions of section 21458(a) of said Code which prohibits the parking, stopping and/or standing of vehicles in a "red zone" and section 42001 of said Code which authorizes the issuance of citations for vehicles parked in violation of any Vehicle Code provision and allows imposition of a fine of up to fifty dollars ($50.00) for such violation shall, upon appropriate posting thereof, be enforceable within such privately owned and maintained roads: 
On that parcel of land shown on the maps entitled "Farm Hill Vista Condominium Subdivision and Plan" as it is recorded in volume 73, pages 35 through 42, on December 7, 1971 in the office of the recorder of the County of San Mateo, State of California. 
(Ord. No. 1899, § 1, 6-25-84)  
Sec. 20.91.5. - ENFORCEMENT OF REGULATIONS PERTAINING TO PARKING SPACES DESIGNATED FOR PHYSICALLY HANDICAPPED PERSONS ON CERTAIN PRIVATELY OWNED OFF-STREET PARKING FACILITIES: 
Pursuant to the provisions of section 21107.8 of the Vehicle Code of the State of California it is hereby found and declared that the following privately owned and maintained off-street parking facilities are generally held open for use of the public for purposes of vehicular parking and, therefore, the provisions of section 22507.8 of said Code pertaining to parking or standing any vehicle in a stall or space designated for physically handicapped persons shall, upon appropriate posting thereof, be enforceable within such parking facilities: The parking lot and facilities appurtenant to Kaiser Hospital, located at 1150 Veterans Boulevard. 
(Ord. No. 1818, § 1, 4-14-80)  
Sec. 20.92. - PARKING FOR CERTAIN PURPOSES PROHIBITED: 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
A.  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
B.  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 123)  
Sec. 20.93. - PARKING PROHIBITED ON PUBLIC STREETS DURING SPECIFIED HOURS FOR STREET SWEEPING PURPOSES: 
A.  No person shall stop, park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, on any public street within the City during the time of the day in which the street is scheduled to be swept, as indicated by street signs posted in accordance with section 22507.6 of the Vehicle Code. All streets during the specified street sweeping hours are designated as no parking zones and shall be sign posted as such. 
B.  Authority is delegated to the city manager or his/her designee to establish a schedule for the regular sweeping of streets within the City, and in connection therewith, to determine the day of the week and time of day during which parking will be prohibited on each street included within the schedule. 
(Ord. No. 2332, § 1, 6-23-2008)  
Sec. 20.94. - AUTHORITY TO PLACE AND OBEDIENCE TO EMERGENCY PARKING SIGNS: 
A.  Whenever the City Manager shall determine that an emergency traffic congestion is likely to result from the holding of public or private assemblages, gatherings or functions, or for other reasons, the City Manager shall have power and authority to order temporary signs to be erected or posted indicating that the operation, parking or standing of vehicles is prohibited on such streets and alleys as the City Manager shall direct during the time such temporary signs are in place. Such signs shall remain in place only during the existence of such emergency, and the City Manager shall cause such signs to be removed promptly thereafter. 
B.  When signs authorized by the provisions of this Section are in place giving notice thereof, no person shall operate, park or stand any vehicle contrary to the directions and provisions of such signs. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 131)  
Sec. 20.95. - PARKING FOR MORE THAN SEVENTY-TWO CONSECUTIVE HOURS PROHIBITED; REMOVAL BY POLICE: 
A.  No person who owns or has possession, custody, or control of any vehicle shall park or leave standing such vehicle upon a street, alley, or highway, or a parking lot owned or leased by, or under vehicular regulatory jurisdiction of, the City for more than a consecutive period of seventy-two (72) hours. 
B.  In the event a vehicle is parked or left standing upon a street, alley, or highway, or a parking lot owned or leased by, or under vehicular regulatory jurisdiction of, the City in excess of a consecutive period of seventy-two (72) hours, any member of the Police Department authorized by the Chief of Police may remove the vehicle from the street or highway in the manner and subject to the requirements of section 22650 et seq., of the Vehicle Code of the State. For purposes of this Section, a vehicle shall be deemed parked or left standing if it has not been moved at least one (1) vehicle length as measured by the length of the vehicle in question within the aforesaid seventy-two (72) hour period. 
(Ord. No. 2059, § 1, 1-25-1993; Ord. No. 2124, § 1, 6-2-1997; Ord. No. 2441, § 5, 2-12-18)  
Sec. 20.95.1. - OVERTIME PARKING; ISSUANCE OF CITATION; PAYMENT OF FINE: 
A.  If a vehicle shall remain parked in a parking space beyond the parking time limit fixed for such parking space in accordance with the provisions of this Division, such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time in that event, and the parking of a vehicle overtime or beyond the period of legal parking time in any such part of a street where parking is limited to a specific period of time shall be a violation of this Division. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this Division for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of, or operated by such person to be parked overtime or beyond the period of legal parking time established for any parking space. 
B.  It shall be the duty of each police officer or parking enforcement deputy to take the state vehicle license of such vehicle; the time, place, and date of such overparking; and make of such vehicle; and issue, in writing, a citation for illegal parking in the same form and subject to the same procedure provided for by the law of the State applicable to traffic violations within the City. 
C.  Any operator or owner of a vehicle to whom a citation has been issued in accordance with the preceding subsection may, within fifteen (15) (business) days of the time of the issuance of such citation, pay to the appropriate court, as a penalty for the full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of forty dollars ($40.00). The mailing in a sealed envelope properly addressed through the United States mail, of a check, money order or postal order, within fifteen (15) (business) days from the time of issuance of the citation, or notice of such violation, or the deposit at the City Hall of the sum of forty dollars ($40.00) within such fifteen (15) (business) days constitutes compliance with this provision. Delivery of such envelope shall be the responsibility of such owner or operator. The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within said fifteen (15) (business) days shall render such owner or operator subject to the penalties provided for violations of the provisions of this Division. 
(Ord. No. 1663, § 1, 2-2-1976; Ord. No. 1786, § 1, 6-4-1979; Ord. No. 1834, § 1, 1-26-1981; Ord. No. 1838, § 1, 4-20-1981; Ord. No. 1908, § 7, 4-15-1985; Ord. No. 2155, § 1, 12-7-1998; Ord. No. 2244, § 1, 2-24-2003; Ord. No. 2272, § 1, 8-9-2004) 
(Ord. No. 2349, § 1, 12-14-2009; Ord. No. 2362, § 1, 2-7-2011)  
Sec. 20.95.2. - PARKING BAIL SCHEDULES: 
For all Vehicle Code violations and for all parking violations (other than those listed in Sections 20.95.1, 20.132, 20.191, 20.210, and Division 11 of this Chapter), the following procedure shall apply: 
A.  It shall be the duty of each police officer or parking enforcement deputy to take the state vehicle license of such vehicles; the time, place, and date of such overtime parking; and make of such vehicle; and issue, in writing, a citation for illegal parking the same form and subject to the same procedure provided for by the law of the State applicable to traffic violations within the City. 
B.  Any operator or owner of a vehicle to whom a citation has been issued in accordance with the preceding subsection may, within fifteen (15) business days of the time of the issuance of such citation, pay to the appropriate court, as a penalty for the full satisfaction of such violation, the sum of forty dollars ($40.00) plus applicable surcharges established by resolution. The mailing, in a sealed envelope properly addressed through the United States mail of a check, money order, or postal order, within fifteen (15) business days from the time of issuance of the citation, or notice of such violation, or the deposit with the court of the sum of forty dollars ($40.00), plus applicable surcharges, within such fifteen (15) business days constitutes compliance with this provision. Delivery of such envelope shall be the responsibility of such owner or operator. The failure of such owner or operator to make such payment within said fifteen (15) business days shall render such owner or operator subject to the penalties provided for violation of the provisions of this Division. 
(Ord. No. 1786, § 2, 6-4-1979; Ord. No. 1885, § 1, 11-21-1983; Ord. No. 1908, § 8, 4-15-1985; Ord. No. 1958, § 3, 9-14-1987; Ord. No. 2155, § 2, 12-7-1998; Ord. No. 2244, § 2, 2-24-2003; Ord. No. 2272, § 2, 8-9-2004) 
(Ord. No. 2349, § 2, 12-14-2009; Ord. No. 2362, § 2, 2-7-2011)

Former § 20.96.1 pertained to "Parking of Vehicles With a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating of More Than Five Thousand (5,000) Pounds for More Than Two Consecutive Hours Prohibited; Removal By Police," and was derived from Ord. Sec. 20.97. - PARKING PROHIBITED AT CERTAIN DESIGNATED TIMES ON DESIGNATED STREETS; APPLICATION OF SECTION ON SATURDAYS, SUNDAYS AND HOLIDAYS—GENERALLY: 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle during the times indicated on such signs upon any of the streets specified in Sections 20.97.1 through 20.97.21 of this Division, inclusive. The provisions of this Section shall not be applicable on Saturdays, Sundays or holidays except as otherwise provided. 
(Ord. No. 1120, § 2; Ord. No. 1513, § 1, 12-13-1971; Ord. No. 1734, § 1, 12-19-1977)

Sec. 20.99. - ANGLE PARKING PERMITTED ON CERTAIN DESIGNATED STREETS:[11] 
In accordance with Section 20.85 of this Division, and when signs or markings are in place giving notice thereof, drivers of vehicles may stand or park a vehicle only as indicated by such marks or signs on the following streets or portions thereof: 
A.  Angle parking to the curb: both sides of Allerton Street between Bradford Street and Brewster Avenue. 
B.  Angle parking to the curb: northerly side of Arguello Street, between Marshall Street and twenty feet (20') east of Bradford Street; northerly side, between Bradford Street and ninety feet (90') east of Brewster Avenue; and southerly side, between Brewster Avenue and seventy-five feet (75') west of Marshall Street. 
C.  Angle parking to the curb: easterly side of Bradford Street, between Arguello Street and Winslow Street; westerly side, between Arguello Street and forty feet (40') south of Winslow Street; northerly side, between Walnut Street and fifty feet (50') east of Middlefield Road; southerly side, between Middlefield Road and sixty feet (60') east of Middlefield Road; southerly side, between Jefferson Avenue and one hundred fifty feet (150') west of Main Street; and southerly side, between Main Street and one hundred feet (100') west of Walnut Street. 
D.  Angle parking to the curb: both sides of Broadway between Marshall Street and two hundred thirty feet (230') east of Jefferson Avenue; and both sides, between Main Street and three hundred feet (300') east of Main Street. 
E.  Angle parking to the curb: easterly side of Fuller Street, between Arguello Street and Winslow Street; westerly side, between eighty feet (80') north of Arguello Street and sixty feet (60') south of Warren Street; and westerly side, between Warren Street and Winslow Street. 
F.  Angle parking to the curb: both sides of Hamilton Street between Theatre Street and Marshall Street. 
G.  Angle parking to the curb: both sides of Marshall Street between Walnut Street and Maple Street. 
H. Sec. 20.100. - ALL-NIGHT PARKING PROHIBITED—FOR VEHICLES ON CERTAIN DESIGNATED STREETS: 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle on any of the streets or portions of streets described as follows for a period of time longer than one hour between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of any day: 
A.  Arguello Street, both sides, Bradford Street to Broadway. 
B.  Arch Street, both sides, Brewster Avenue to Broadway. 
C.  Broadway, both sides, Chestnut Street to Clinton Street. 
D.  California Street, both sides, Broadway to James Avenue. 
E.  El Camino Real, both sides, northerly to southerly City limits. 
F.  Hamilton Street, both sides, Marshall Street to Theatre Street. 
G.  James Avenue, both sides, El Camino Real to Southern Pacific Station. 
H.  Jefferson Avenue, both sides, Marshall Street to Middlefield Road. 
I.  Main Street, both sides, Bayshore Highway to El Camino Real. 
J.  Maple Street, both sides, Middlefield Road to El Camino Real. 
K.  Middlefield Road, both sides, Marshall Street to Main Street. 
L.  Perry Street, both sides, Brewster Avenue to Broadway. 
M.  Theatre Street, both sides, Hamilton Street to Middlefield Road. 
N.  Winklebleck Street, both sides, El Camino Real to the Southern Pacific Station. 
O.  Winslow Street, both sides, Marshall Street to Broadway; east side, from a point fifty-five feet (55') south of Broadway to a point one hundred fifty one feet (151') south of Broadway; and west side, from a point fifty-five feet (55') south of Broadway to a point two hundred ten feet (210') south of Broadway. 
(Ord. No. 758, §§ 152, 194; Ord. No. 919, § 6; Ord. No. 1737, § 1, 1-9-1978)  
Sec. 20.101. - PARKING OF OVERSIZED COMMERCIAL VEHICLES PROHIBITED; REMOVAL BY POLICE: 
A.  For purposes of this Section, the term "commercial vehicle" shall have the meaning ascribed to it by Vehicle Code Section 260, and the term "oversized" shall mean a commercial vehicle that exceeds twenty-four and one-half (24.5) feet in overall length (including any load or accessory thereon) or that has a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of more than eight thousand (8,000) pounds. 
B.  When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park or leave standing any oversized commercial vehicle upon the street for more than a consecutive period of two (2) hours. This limitation on parking shall be effective twenty-four (24) hours daily. For purposes of this subsection B, a vehicle shall be deemed parked or left standing if it has not been moved at least one (1) vehicle length as measured by the length of the vehicle in question within the aforesaid two (2) hour period. 
C.  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection B of this Section, no person shall stop, stand or park any oversized commercial vehicle at any time on any street in the City for a period of time longer than one hour between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. of any day. 
D.  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsections B and C of this Section, no person shall stop, stand or park any oversized commercial vehicle in a residential district at any time; provided, however, any person may stop, stand or park any such vehicle in a residential district while necessary to load or unload property therefrom, or when such stopping, standing or parking is reasonably necessary in the performance of a service to or upon any property in the block where such vehicle is stopped, standing or parked. 
E.  In the event a vehicle is stopped, parked, or left standing upon a street in violation of this Section, any member of the Police Department authorized by the Chief of Police may remove the vehicle from the street or highway in the manner and subject to the requirements of Section 22650 et seq., of the Vehicle Code of the State. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 152; Ord. No. 919, § 6, Ord. No. 1439, § 1, 11-24-69; Ord. No. 1971, §§ 3, 4, 7-25-88) 
(Ord. No. 2441, § 7, 2-12-18) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2441, § 7, adopted February 12, 2018, amended § 20.101 to read as set out herein. Previously § 20.101 was titled "All-Night Parking Prohibited—For Trucks, Buses, Trailers, etc., on Any Street."  
Sec. 20.102. - PARKING IN AREA ADJACENT TO SOUTHERN PACIFIC STATION—NO PARKING ZONE; MARKING OF CURB: 
A no-parking zone is hereby created in the area along the northeasterly curb of the thoroughfare leading from the Southern Pacific Passenger Station to James Avenue, which zone is described as follows: 
Beginning at a point at the easterly end of the curb at the northeasterly corner of the Southern Pacific Passenger Station, thence approximately one hundred feet (100') more or less in a southerly direction along the curb to the southerly edge of a driveway leading to the Southern Pacific baggage room. 
The curb shall be painted red in accordance with the provisions of section 21458 of the Vehicle Code of the State. 
(Ord. No. 641, § 2)  
Sec. 20.103. - PARKING IN AREA ADJACENT TO SOUTHERN PACIFIC STATION—FIFTEEN-MINUTE PARKING ZONE; MARKING OF CURB: 
A fifteen-minute parking zone is hereby created in the area along the northeasterly curb of the thoroughfare leading from the Southern Pacific Passenger Station to James Avenue, which zone is described as follows: 
Commencing at a point on the southerly edge of the driveway leading to the Southern Pacific baggage room and extending approximately fifty feet (50') in a southerly direction on the easterly curb of the thoroughfare adjacent to the Southern Pacific Station at the end of James Avenue. 
The curb shall be painted green in accordance with the provisions of section 21458 of the Vehicle Code of the State. 
(Ord. No. 641, § 2)  
Sec. 20.104. - RESTRICTED—USE PARKING ZONE CREATED ON PORTION OF WINSLOW STREET: 
A.  A restricted-use parking zone, for the use hereinafter described, is hereby created in the area along the easterly curb of Winslow Street from the southerly edge of a driveway leading to a loading area of the Hall of Justice and Records southerly to a point one hundred five feet (105') from said southerly edge of said driveway. 
   Said zone shall be and remain in effect so long as the City is compensated, in advance, for the use of said zone in an amount equal to the maximum amount that would be collected by five (5) parking meters during their hours of operation pursuant to the schedule set forth in Section 20.132.21 of this Code. 
   The use of said zone shall be limited to the parking of vehicles owned by governmental agencies and used for law enforcement activities. 
B.  When the zone established in subsection A hereof is appropriately marked in accordance with Section 20.105 hereof, no person shall stop, stand, or park any vehicle, other than the vehicles authorized in subsection A of this Section, at any time within any portion of the zone established in said subsection A. 
(Ord. No. 641, § 3; Ord. No. 1512, § 1, 12-13-71)  
Sec. 20.104.5. - MAINTENANCE OF SIGNS RELATIVE TO SECTIONS 20.102—20.104: 
The City Manager is hereby directed to provide and maintain such official signs on the thoroughfares and streets mentioned in Sections 20.102, 20.103, and 20.104, as will properly indicate the traffic regulations contained in Sections 20.102, 20.103, and 20.104. 
(Ord. No. 1512, § 2, 12-13-71)  
DIVISION 2. - TOW-AWAY ZONES 
 
Sec. 20.105. - DESIGNATED; PARKING RESTRICTIONS THEREIN: 
In accordance with Section 20.106, and when appropriate signs have been erected, any vehicle parked on any of the streets, highways or offstreet parking facilities designated in this Section during the corresponding times indicated, shall be subject to removal, pursuant to the provisions of Section 20.107. 
A.  Bowspirit Drive: Both sides, from Compass Drive to Lanyard Drive: No parking at any time. 
B.  Bridge Parkway: Both sides, from Marine Parkway to Tiller Lane: No parking at any time. 
C.  El Camino Real: 
1.  Northeasterly side, Broadway to Winklebleck Street: No parking at any time. 
2.  Southwesterly side, from a point one hundred ninety-five feet (195') south of the southerly line of Brewster Avenue to a point four hundred feet (400') south of the southerly line of Broadway: No parking at any time. 
3.  Northeasterly side, from Charter Street to Nottingham Avenue: No parking at any time. 
4.  Northeasterly side, from a point sixty-two feet (62') northwesterly of the centerline of Dumbarton Avenue to a point eighty-five feet (85') southeasterly of the centerline of Dumbarton Avenue: No parking at any time. 
5.  Southwesterly side, from a point seventy-five feet (75') northwesterly of the centerline of Center Street to a point fifty feet (50') southeasterly of the centerline of Center Street: No parking at any time. 
6.  Southwesterly side, from the extension of the southeasterly line of Buckingham Avenue to Renato Court: No parking at any time. 
7.  Northeasterly side, from Main Street to Lathrop Street: No parking at any time. 
8.  Southwesterly side, from a point three hundred twenty-five feet (325') northwesterly of the centerline of Oak Avenue to Redwood Avenue: No parking at any time. 
9.  Southwesterly side, from a point eighty feet (80') northwesterly from the centerline of Harrison Avenue to a point one hundred forty feet (140') southeasterly from the centerline of Jefferson Avenue: No parking at any time. 
10.  Northeasterly side, from a point one hundred seventy-five feet (175') northwesterly from the centerline of Jefferson Avenue to a point one hundred seventy-five feet (175') southeasterly from the centerline of Wilson Street: No parking at any time. 
D.  Jefferson Avenue: 
1.  Northwesterly side, from Adams Street to a point two hundred ten feet (210') northeasterly from the centerline of El Camino Real: No parking at any time. 
2.  Southeasterly side, from a point one hundred forty-five feet (145') southwesterly from the centerline of El Camino Real to Franklin Street: No parking at any time. 
E.  Marine Parkway: Both sides, from a point six hundred forty feet (640') westerly of Twin Dolphin Parkway to Bridge Parkway: No parking at any time. 
F.  Peninsula Parkway: Both sides, from a point two hundred feet (200') southwesterly of Bridge Parkway to Shell Parkway: No parking at any time. 
G.  Shell Parkway: Both sides, from Peninsula Parkway to Davit Lane: No parking at any time. 
H.  Intersection of Arguello Street and Bradford Streets: Arguello Street extending from Marshall Street to a point approximately five hundred thirty feet (530') northwest toward Brewster Avenue, and on Bradford Street from Arguello Street to a point approximately one hundred fifty feet (150') northeast (mid-block) toward Warren Street. No parking from two o'clock (2:00) A.M. through three o'clock (3:00) P.M. Saturday, including holidays, April through November of every week of said months. 
(Ord. No. 2064, § 1, 8-2-93) 
(Ord. No. 2412, § 3, 5-18-15)  
Sec. 20.106. - USE OF ZONES; INFORMATION TO BE SHOWN ON SIGNS: 
No person shall park any vehicle on any street, highway or offstreet parking facility or any portion thereof, designated in Section 20.105 when signs are in place designating the street, highway or offstreet parking facility or such portion thereof as a tow-away zone. When such signs are in place designating a street, highway or a portion thereof, as a two-away zone, the area adjacent to the curb shall be used exclusively as a traffic lane for moving traffic during the hours designated on the signs. 
Every sign erected pursuant to this Section shall indicate the hours during which parking is prohibited, that any vehicle in violation thereof shall be towed away, and the telephone number where information concerning vehicles towed away may be obtained. 
(Ord. No. 2064, § 2, 8-2-93)  
Sec. 20.107. - RIGHT TO REMOVE UNLAWFULLY PARKED VEHICLES; NOTICE TO POLICE DEPARTMENT UPON REMOVAL: 
Any vehicle parked in violation of Section 20.106 may be removed pursuant to the provisions of section 22650 et seq. of the Vehicle Code of the State. 
In addition to any notice required by such section, the person causing the removal of any vehicle pursuant to this Section shall immediately notify the Police Department of the City of the fact of the removal, the vehicle type, the vehicle license plate number and the owner's name if it can be ascertained. 
(Ord. No. 980, § 2)  
DIVISION 3. - STOPPING FOR LOADING OR UNLOADING ONLY; RESTRICTED USE[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2409, § 3, adopted November 17, 2014, amended div. 3 to read as set out herein. Previously div. 3 was titled stopping for loading or unloading only. 
 
Sec. 20.108. - AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH LOADING ZONES OR RESTRICTED USE PARKING ZONES; SIGNAGE AND MARKING OF ZONES: 
A.  The City Manager is hereby authorized to determine and to mark, by signage, curb marking or both, loading zones, passenger loading zones, handicapped parking zones, limited time parking zones, Car Share parking only zones, and electric-charging zones subject to programs and/or regulations adopted by the City and as follows: 
1.  At any place in any business district. 
2.  Elsewhere in front of the entrance to any place of business or in front of any hall or place used for the purpose of public assembly. 
B.  In no event shall more than one-half (½) of the total curb length in any block be reserved for loading zone purposes. 
C.  Loading zones shall be indicated by a yellow paint line stenciled with black letters, "LOADING ONLY," upon the top of all curbs within such zones and/or by signage in compliance with the California Vehicle Code. 
D.  Passenger loading zones shall be indicated by a white line stenciled with black letters, "PASSENGER LOADING ONLY," upon the top of all curbs within such zones and/or by signage in compliance with the California Vehicle Code. 
E.  Handicapped parking zones shall be indicated by a blue paint line stenciled with white letters, "HANDICAPPED PARKING ONLY," upon the top of all curbs within such zones and/or by signage in compliance with the California Vehicle Code. 
F.  Car Share zones or spaces shall be indicated by signage in compliance with the California Vehicle Code. 
G.  Electric-charging zones or spaces shall be indicated by signage in compliance with the California Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 140; Ord. No. 1689, § 1, 1-3-77) 
(Ord. No. 2409, § 3, 11-17-14) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2409, § 3, adopted November 17, 2014, amended § 20.108 to read as set out herein. Previously § 20.108 was titled authority to establish loading zones; marking of zones.  
Sec. 20.109. - CURB MARKINGS OR SIGNAGE TO INDICATE STOPPING AND PARKING REGULATIONS; COMPLIANCE WITH CURB MARKINGS AND SIGNAGE REQUIRED: 
The City Manager is hereby authorized, subject to the provisions and limitations of this Chapter, to place, and when required herein shall place, the following curb markings to indicate parking or standing regulations, and such curb markings shall have the meanings herein set forth: 
A.  Red shall mean no stopping, standing or parking at any time except as permitted by the Vehicle Code of this State, and except that a bus may stop in a red zone marked or signed as a bus zone. 
B.  Yellow shall mean no stopping, standing or parking at any time between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of any day except Sundays and holidays for any purpose other than the loading or unloading of passengers or materials, provided that the loading or unloading of passengers shall not consume more than three (3) minutes nor the loading or unloading of materials more than twenty (20) minutes. 
C.  White shall mean no stopping, standing or parking for any purpose other than loading or unloading of passengers which shall not exceed three (3) minutes, and such restriction shall apply between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of any day except Sundays and holidays and except as follows: 
1.  When such zone is in front of a hotel the restrictions shall apply at all times. 
2.  When such zone is in front of a theater the restrictions shall apply at all times except when such theater is closed, unless more restrictive hours are posted on signage, in which case, the restrictions shall apply during the hours posted. 
3.  When such zone is in front of a school, the restrictions shall apply only when school is in session and then only during the hours posted on signage. 
D.  Green shall mean no standing or parking for longer than twenty (20) minutes at any time between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of any day except Sundays and holidays. 
E.  Blue shall mean no stopping, standing or parking except for vehicles of physically handicapped persons; provided, however, that such vehicles shall be subject to all other parking regulations contained in this Chapter regulating parking on those streets upon which such zone has been designated. 
In addition to or in lieu of curb markings, such restrictions may be indicated by posted signage in compliance with the California Vehicle Code. When the City Manager as authorized under this Chapter has caused curb markings to be placed or signage to be posted, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle adjacent to any such legible curb marking or posted signage in violation of any of the provisions of this Section. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 141; Ord. No. 1689, § 2, 1-3-77) 
(Ord. No. 2409, § 3, 11-17-14) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2409, § 3, adopted November 17, 2014, amended § 20.109 to read as set out herein. Previously § 20.109 was titled curb markings to indicate stopping and parking regulations; compliance with curb markings required. 
State Law reference— Curb markings to indicate parking regulations, Veh. C., § 21458.  
Sec. 20.110. - EFFECT OF PERMISSION TO LOAD OR UNLOAD: 
A.  Permission granted in this Article to stop or stand a vehicle for purposes of loading or unloading materials shall apply only to commercial vehicles and shall not extend beyond the time necessary therefor, and in no event for more than twenty (20) minutes. 
B.  The loading or unloading of materials shall apply only to commercial deliveries, also the delivery or pickup of express and parcel post packages and United States mail. 
C.  Permission granted in this Article to stop or park for purposes of loading or unloading passengers shall include the loading or unloading of personal baggage but shall not extend the time necessary therefor and in no event beyond or for more than three (3) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 142)  
Sec. 20.111. - USE OF LOADING ZONES RESTRICTED: 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any passenger loading zone for any purpose other than the loading or unloading of passengers or materials for such time as is permitted in the preceding Section. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 143)  
Sec. 20.112. - USE OF PASSENGER LOADING ZONES RESTRICTED: 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any passenger loading zone for any purpose other than the loading or unloading of passengers for such time as is specified in Section 20.110. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 144)  
Sec. 20.113. - STANDING, ETC., IN ALLEYS PERMITTED FOR LOADING OR UNLOADING ONLY: 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose other than the loading or unloading of persons or materials in any alley. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 145)  
Sec. 20.114. - AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH BUS ZONES; BUS DEFINED; MARKING OF ZONES; USE BY OTHER VEHICLE PROHIBITED: 
A.  The City Manager is hereby authorized to establish bus zones opposite curb space for the loading and unloading of buses or common carriers of passengers and to determine the location thereof subject to the directives and limitations set forth herein. 
B.  The word "bus" as used in this Section shall mean any motor bus, motor coach, trackless trolley coach, or passenger stage used as a common carrier of passengers. 
C.  No bus zone shall exceed eighty feet (80') in length, except that when satisfactory evidence has been presented to the City Manager showing the necessity therefor, the City Manager may extend bus zones not to exceed a total length of one hundred twenty-five feet (125'). 
D.  Bus zones shall normally be established on the far side of an intersection. 
E.  The City Manager shall paint a red line stenciled with white letters "NO STANDING," together with the words "BUS ZONE" upon the top or side of all curbs and places specified as a bus zone. 
F.  No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle except a bus in a bus zone. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 146) 
State Law reference— Local regulation of bus stands, Veh. C., § 21112.
