The revised map referenced in Section 30.24 shall show all substantive changes in the design, number of lots or shape of lots. Such revised tentative parcel map shall be subject to all provisions of this Chapter and the Subdivision Map Act applicable at the time such revised map is filed, and such map shall show all of the information specified in Section 30.17 insofar as necessary to support any revisions or modifications that may have been made. If the subdivider, prior to the filing of a parcel map, makes changes in the tentative parcel map or statements thereon, the subdivider shall submit such changes to the Planning Director for review by the subdivision committee. All such changes shall be subject to the approval of the Subdivision Committee before a parcel map may be filed. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.26. - EXPIRATION AND EXTENSION OF TENTATIVE PARCEL MAP APPROVALS: 
An approved or conditionally approved tentative parcel map shall expire eighteen (18) months from the date the map was approved, or conditionally approved by the Subdivision Committee. In the event that a water or sewer moratorium is established by the Council, that portion of the eighteen (18) month period remaining at the time the moratorium was imposed shall commence running upon the date when such moratorium is terminated. If any time extensions are granted pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, the Subdivision Committee may require compliance with all provisions of this Chapter or the Subdivision Map Act in effect at the time of such application for extension. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.27. - WITHDRAWAL OF TENTATIVE PARCEL MAP: 
Any subdivider or owner of the property may withdraw the tentative parcel map at any time up until three (3) working days before the map is scheduled to be considered by the Subdivision Committee by submitting a written request therefor to the Planning Director. Upon receipt of such request to withdraw the map, the Planning Director shall notify the Subdivision Committee and all persons and agencies who have previously received copies of said map for review and recommendation. Upon such notification, the tentative parcel map shall be deemed to have been officially withdrawn. No refund in filing fees for such withdrawn map shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.28. - IMPROVEMENTS PRIOR TO FILING PARCEL MAP: 
If the subdivider elects, or is required by the provisions of this Chapter, to install subdivision improvements prior to filing a parcel map but subsequent to approval or conditional approval of a tentative parcel map, the subdivider shall construct all such improvements in compliance with Section 30.86, et seq., and to the approval of the Director of Public Works. All plans, specifications, and all related details to such construction shall be completed to the approval of the Director of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.29. - PROCEDURES FOR PROCESSING PARCEL MAP: 
The following provisions govern the processing of parcel maps: 
A.  Preparation: Within eighteen (18) months after approval or conditional approval of the tentative parcel map, the subdivider may cause a parcel map to be prepared in accordance with the conditions of approval of the tentative parcel map and in compliance with this Chapter and the Subdivision Map Act. Said map, together with prescribed fees and deposits (see Sections 30.70 and 30.71) and a current title report, shall be filed with the Director of Public Works. 
B.  Form and Content: Unless otherwise specified by this Chapter, the form and content of the parcel map shall be as set forth in the Subdivision Map Act. 
C.  Parcel Map Submittal: At least fourteen (14) days prior to the expiration date for the approval of the parcel map, the subdivider shall submit four (4) copies of the map for review to the Director of Public Works. 
D.  Review of Parcel Map: The Director of Public Works shall review such map for compliance with the approved tentative parcel map and the provisions of this Chapter and of the Subdivision Map Act. The Director of Public Works shall within thirty (30) days report to the subdivider in writing what measures, if any, are necessary to bring the map into conformity with the approved or conditionally approved tentative parcel map or with the aforementioned provisions. 
E.  Recording: Upon making a finding that the parcel map is in conformity with the approved or conditionally approved tentative parcel map and that the tentative parcel map is mathematically and technically correct, the Director of Public Works shall so certify on such map, and shall transmit such map to the City Clerk for transmittal to the County Recorder for recordation. After such recordation, the Director of Public Works, at the subdivider's expense, shall cause one set of reproducible polyester base tracings to be prepared for the files of the Department of Public Works. One set of prints from such tracings shall be transmitted to the Planning Department. Two (2) copies of any covenants, conditions and restrictions for the division of land, if any, which have been recorded, shall also be filed with the Department of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Secs. 30.30—30.32. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE III. - TENTATIVE MAP 
 
Sec. 30.33. - TENTATIVE MAP PROCESSING; GENERAL: 
The subdivider shall consult with the Planning Director and shall obtain a check list established by the Planning Director of maps and other supporting documents required by the City for adequate review of the proposed division of land. If in the opinion of the Planning Director, the complexity of the proposed subdivision warrants the preparation of a preliminary design map, the subdivider shall file such preliminary design map and other information deemed by the Planning Director to be necessary to describe essential features of the property and the proposed uses and development. The subdivider shall submit eight (8) copies of the map and the required fees (see Section 30.70) with such filing. The Planning Director shall, upon receipt of an acceptable preliminary design map and other documentation, transmit copies to the Plan Review Committee. Within fifteen (15) working days after the Planning Director has received an acceptable preliminary design map, the Plan Review Committee shall review the map and make such general recommendations to the subdivider as it may deem appropriate. Within ten (10) working days after such committee meeting the Planning Director shall transmit in writing a copy of such recommendations to the subdivider and other interested parties. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.34. - PREPARATION OF TENTATIVE MAP: 
The subdivider shall cause a tentative map to be prepared in accordance with the Subdivision Map Act and with the provisions of this Chapter. Prior to preparation of said map, or concurrently therewith, the subdivider shall make application for an environmental review of the project as proposed on such map for compliance with the environmental regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.35. - INFORMATION REQUIRED: 
The tentative map shall contain or be accompanied by the following information: 
A.  The tract name and number; date of preparation; north point and scale. 
B.  Names, addresses and telephone numbers of the record owner, the subdivider and the person who prepared the map. (The registration or license number of the preparer shall also be supplied.) 
C.  Subdivision boundaries and acreage to the nearest one-tenth ( 1/10 ) acre. 
D.  Sufficient legal description to define the boundaries of the proposed subdivision. 
E.  A vicinity map showing: 
1.  The location of the proposed subdivision in relation to the major street system in the vicinity of such subdivision. 
2.  The location, name, and presently improved width of adjacent streets of such subdivision. 
F.  The name and number of adjacent subdivisions, showing lot and block or parcel numbers for adjoining lots. (An aerial photograph may be required at a scale of not less than one inch (1?) for each two hundred feet (200') showing the approximate boundaries of the subdivision, and including the streets and lot line in addition to the above.) 
G.  Location, names and widths of existing and proposed streets, and any difference from streets shown on any specific plan which covers all or part of the land to be subdivided. 
H.  Existing topographic information: 
1.  Existing topograph of the proposed site, which shall extend at least one hundred feet (100') beyond the proposed subdivision boundaries. On flat lands, where the predominant slopes are five percent (5%) or less, a contour interval of not to exceed one foot (1') shall be used. Where the predominant slopes are between five (5%) and ten percent (10%), a contour interval of not to exceed two feet (2') shall be used. Where slopes exceed ten percent (10%), a contour interval of five feet (5') shall be used. The source of such topographic information shown on such map shall be indicated. 
2.  Buildings, driveways, fences, retaining walls, swimming pools (including whether such structures are to remain or be removed), and the distances between buildings, and between buildings and proposed or existing property lines. 
3.  Groves of trees and the location, species, and diameter of all individual trees with a trunk diameter of four inches (4?) or more (twelve and one-half inches (12 ½?) circumference) as measured at four feet (4') above natural grade, and other significant vegetation, indicating whether removal is intended and showing trees and vegetation to be planted other than street trees. 
4.  Approximate location of any area which may be subject to inundation; the location, width and direction of all watercourses. 
I.  Location, width and nature of all existing pedestrian paths; public areas, conservation easements; and public utilities easements. 
J.  Existing utilities: 
1.  The location and size of existing storm drains; sanitary sewers, gas and water lines. 
2.  The location of existing fire hydrants, power and telephone or communications lines and other public utilities. 
3.  All provisions for drainage, flood and erosion control. 
4.  Source of water supply and method and location of sewage disposal facility. 
K.  Statement of the existing land use and the proposed land use with an indication as to the respective proportions of the total area of the subdivision to be used by each type of use. 
L.  Location, type and size of the improvements proposed to be made or installed, including: 
1.  Approximate finished grade elevations and contours at intervals required for existing contours. Where the effective use of the land to be subdivided necessitates extensive cuts and fills, the proposed grading shall be clearly shown by means of both contours and supplemental cross sections. Approximate finished elevations at all lot corners shall be made. 
2.  Radii of all curves. 
3.  Location, size, and/or slope and approximate elevations of sanitary sewers, storm drains, water facilities, fire hydrants, as well as all provisions for drainage, flood and erosion control (see Section 30.90). 
4.  Profiles of street center lines and other features, if required by the Director of Public Works. (All elevations shall be indicated to the nearest one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of a foot and shall be referenced to elevations according to Redwood City datum.) 
5.  Typical cross sections of all streets, and when required by the Director of Public Works, detail of curbs, gutters, walks, trails, and other improvements drawn to scale and clearly showing all details thereof. 
6.  Location, species and size of all proposed street trees and all other landscaping within public rights-of-way and easements. 
M.  Statement of the improvements proposed to be made or previously installed by private utilities or public agencies and a statement from such utilities or agencies as to the adequacy of such installations and the rights-of-way or easements for the proposed improvements. 
N.  Lot lines; approximate dimensions of all lots, including the area of each to within approximately one percent (1%) accuracy; block and lot numbers in consecutive sequence. 
O.  Accompanying reports: 
1.  A preliminary title report from a title company providing the following: Owners of record and all encumbrances including easements, reservations, restrictions, liens and covenants. 
2.  Preliminary soils report and the report of an engineering geologist, if the location of the proposed subdivision is in the hillside areas southwesterly of the Alameda de las Pulgas. All other subdivisions shall comply with the soils and geologic provisions of Section 30.83 and Section 30.84. 
3.  Any proposed conditions, covenants and restrictions, if any, for the proposed development. 
P.  Designation of the proposed units, and the proposed sequence of construction, if the subdivision is to be developed in units. 
Q.  A blank three inch (3?) by six inch (6?) (minimum) space for the certificates, conditions and approval, and other similar items; such space to be reserved on the title page. 
R.  Such other information as may be required to fulfill the purposes of this Chapter or the Subdivision Map Act in relation to the particular land to be subdivided. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.36. - ACCEPTANCE FOR FILING; CERTIFICATION: 
The tentative map shall be deemed ready for filing after an environmental review has been made of the project pursuant to the provisions of the environmental regulations. A tentative map will thereafter be deemed accepted as filed when the Planning Director finds that the map is complete and contains the information required on the checklist established pursuant to Section 30.33 and when ten (10) copies of the map have been submitted with the required fees by the subdivider. The Planning Director shall report to the subdivider on the completeness of the submitted map within thirty (30) days. Should the Planning Director find that a resubmitted map does not meet the test of completeness, the Planning Director shall have additional periods of not more than thirty (30) days for review until such map is in reasonable compliance with the provisions of this Chapter as to form and content. The Planning Director shall certify such finding and report the date thereof. The Planning Commission shall have fifty (50) days from such certification to approve, disapprove, or conditionally approve the tentative map and to report its action to the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.37. - DISTRIBUTION OF MAPS; SETTING HEARING DATE: 
The Planning Director shall transmit one copy of the map and any accompanying data to each member of the Plan Review Committee, and to any other agency he may deem to be affected by the proposed subdivision. The Planning Director shall within ten (10) days of acceptance of the tentative map for filing send notice of such filing to the governing board of any elementary or high school district within the boundaries of which the subdivision is proposed to be located in accordance with the provisions of section 66455.7 of the Government Code. The Planning Director shall also transmit such material to the Health Officer: 
A.  If the subdivision includes public or private bodies of water usable for water contact sports, and 
B.  If the Health Officer's review of such features is reasonably necessary to protect the public and further the purposes of this Chapter. 
The Planning Director shall set a date for a hearing before the Plan Review Committee not more than fifteen (15) working days from receipt of the additional prints to be supplied by the subdivider pursuant to Section 30.36, and shall notify the subdivider and any other agencies to which prints have been transmitted of the date of such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.38. - AGENCY REPORTS: 
In the event that an agency to which the tentative map was referred submits a written report of its findings to the Planning Director at least three (3) working days prior to the hearing date of the Plan Review Committee, the Plan Review Committee shall consider the contents thereof. 
If such reports are not received within the prescribed time, the Plan Review Committee shall note such fact in its findings and recommendations. It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to comply with the lawful requirements of such agencies regardless of whether or not a report has been submitted to the Plan Review Committee by any such agency. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.39. - DUTIES OF THE PLAN REVIEW COMMITTEE: 
When reviewing the tentative map, the Plan Review Committee shall: 
A.  Provide an opportunity for: 
1.  Comments of the subdivider and/or his engineer (surveyor); and 
2.  Comments of such other officials and utilities and agencies that may have submitted a report. 
B.  Consider the proposed subdivision as it relates to: 
1.  Environmental review documents. 
2.  All elements of the general plan and its policies. 
3.  Relevant adopted specific plans and the Zoning Ordinance. 
4.  Degree of conformance with adopted development design standards and specifications. 
5.  Adequacy of provisions for fire safety and general safety as determined by the Fire Chief. 
6.  Utility requirements. 
C.  Review an application for exceptions, if any, as provided in Section 30.69. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.40. - ACTION OF THE PLAN REVIEW COMMITTEE: 
After completion of its review of the proposed tentative map, the Plan Review Committee shall within five (5) working days transmit copies of its findings and recommendations to the subdivider and to the Planning Commission. The Planning Director shall place the matter on the earliest Planning Commission meeting agenda that will afford the Commission adequate time to review the proposed map and that will permit compliance with public hearing notice requirements, if any. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.41. - ACTION OF PLANNING COMMISSION; CONSIDERATIONS REQUIRED: 
The Planning Commission shall consider the following before approving, conditionally approving, or disapproving the proposed tentative map: 
A.  Environmental review documents. 
B.  The report of findings and recommendations, if any, of the Plan Review Committee. 
C.  Consistency with adopted general plan, relevant specific plans, policies and standards of the City. 
D.  Application for exceptions, if any. 
E.  Staff reports. 
F.  Testimony of the subdivider and/or his engineer (surveyor). 
G.  Public testimony. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.42. - REQUIRED FINDINGS: 
The Planning Commission shall disapprove a tentative map if it makes any of the following findings: 
A.  The map, design or improvements of the proposed subdivision are inconsistent with the general or specific plans, the zoning ordinance, or subdivision improvement requirements. 
B.  The site is not physically suited for the proposed type or density of development. 
C.  The design or proposed improvements are likely to cause substantial environmental damage, or substantially and avoidably injure fish, wildlife or their habitat, or cause serious public health problems. 
D.  The design or improvements of the proposed subdivision will conflict with essential public easements for access through, or use of, property within the proposed subdivision, unless acceptable alternate public easements will be provided. 
E.  The reasons submitted for the granting of any exceptions applied for do not comply with requirements for findings described in Section 30.69, and the tentative map is deemed not workable without the granting of such exceptions. 
F.  Such other findings of conflict with written public policy or with the public interest as the Planning Commission may determine. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.43. - REPORT TO SUBDIVIDER; SUBMITTAL OF NEW MAPS: 
The action of the Planning Commission shall be reported in writing to the subdivider within five (5) working days accompanied by one copy of the tentative map as approved. One copy of the approved tentative map and accompanying data shall be filed with both the Planning Department and the Department of Public Works. If the approved tentative map has been substantially modified at the request of the Planning Commission or if substantive revisions have been made by the subdivider to such map from the submitted tentative map, the subdivider shall prepare and submit a new map, for approval by the aforementioned departments. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.44. - TENTATIVE MAP CHANGES, REVISIONS: 
The revised map referenced in Section 30.43 shall show all substantive changes in the design, number of lots or shape of lots. Such revised tentative map shall be subject to all provisions of this Chapter and the Subdivision Map Act applicable at the time such map is revised, and such map shall show all of the information specified in Section 30.35 insofar as necessary to support any revisions or modifications that may have been made. If the subdivider, prior to the filing of a final map, makes changes in the map or statements thereon, the subdivider shall submit such changes to the Planning Director for review by the Plan Review Committee. The Plan Review Committee shall submit its recommendations to the Planning Commission. All such changes shall be subject to the approval of the Planning Commission before a final map may be filed. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.45. - EXPIRATION AND EXTENSION OF TENTATIVE MAP APPROVALS: 
An approved or conditionally approved tentative map shall expire eighteen (18) months from the date the map was approved, or conditionally approved by the Planning Commission. In the event that a water or sewer moratorium is established by the Council, that portion of the eighteen (18) month period remaining at the time the moratorium was imposed shall commence running upon the date when such moratorium is terminated. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.46. - WITHDRAWAL OF TENTATIVE MAP: 
Any subdivider or owner of the property may withdraw the tentative map at any time up to three (3) working days before the map is scheduled to be considered by the Planning Commission by submitting a written request therefor to the Planning Director. Upon receipt of such request to withdraw the map, the Planning Director shall notify the Planning Commission and all persons and agencies which had previously received copies of said map for review and recommendation. Upon such notification, the tentative map shall be deemed to have been officially withdrawn. No refund in filing fees for such withdrawn map shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.47. - IMPROVEMENTS PRIOR TO FILING FINAL MAP: 
If the subdivider elects, or is required by the provisions of this Chapter, to install subdivision improvements prior to filing a final map but subsequent to approval or conditional approval of a tentative map, the subdivider shall construct all such improvements in compliance with Sections 30.86, et seq., and to the approval of the Director of Public Works. All plans, specifications, and other details of construction shall also be completed to the approval of the Director of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Secs. 30.48—30.50. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE IV. - FINAL MAP 
 
Sec. 30.51. - PREPARATION: 
Pursuant to the provisions of the Subdivision Map Act and of this Chapter, the subdivider shall cause the real property included within the approved tentative map, or any part of the area to be subdivided, to be surveyed and a final map prepared in accordance with the approved or conditionally approved tentative map. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.52. - ADDITIONAL CERTIFICATIONS REQUIRED: 
In addition to certificates required by the provisions of the Subdivision Map Act, the City may require additional certificates, as determined by the Director of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.53. - FILING FINAL MAP: 
The subdivider shall submit to the Director of Public Works the following items: 
A.  Required filing fees. 
B.  Three (3) complete sets of blueline or blackline prints of the final map for checking purposes. 
C.  A traverse sheet showing the mathematical computations, closure, and area calculations in a form approved by the Director of Public Works. 
D.  Copies of complete field notes, showing references, ties, locations, elevations, and other necessary data relating to monuments and benchmarks set in accordance with the requirements of this Chapter in a form approved by the Director of Public Works. 
E.  A statement that any improvements that have been completed prior to the filing of the final map have been completed in accordance with the plans and specifications as approved by the Director of Public Works, or a statement that the subdivider intends to install such improvements in the future and will enter into an agreement guaranteeing their installation by improvement security as specified in Section 30.79 through Section 30.82. 
F.  Three (3) copies of all plans, profiles, cross sections, and the specifications for the required subdivision improvements which have not been previously submitted to and approved by the Director of Public Works pursuant to the provisions of Section 30.86. 
G.  Three (3) copies of any conditions, covenants and restrictions for the proposed development. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.54. - REVIEW OF FINAL MAP: 
Upon receipt of the items required in Section 30.53, the Director of Public Works shall within ten (10) working days examine the map for conformity with the tentative map. If the Director of Public Works determines that the final map does not conform substantially to the tentative map, he shall advise the subdivider in what aspects the final map must be corrected to achieve conformity with said tentative map. 
Upon determination by the Director of Public Works that the final map is in substantial conformance with said tentative map, he shall within fifteen (15) working days review the final map for: 
A.  Sufficiency of affidavits and acknowledgments. 
B.  Correctness of survey and mathematical data. 
C.  Compliance with provisions of the Subdivision Map Act and this Chapter. 
D.  Sufficiency and adequacy of public utility easements for affected public utilities or private agencies. 
One copy of the final map shall be returned to the subdivider with notations as to errors or omissions, or a statement by the Director of Public Works that the final map is correct. Thereafter, the subdivider shall submit to the Director of Public Works the original tracings with required certificates and two (2) complete sets of blueline prints on cloth, all of which shall contain the required original signatures for transmittal to the City Clerk. When the final map is found to be correct, the data shown thereon or submitted therewith is sufficient, and all applicable provisions of the Subdivision Map Act and this Chapter have been complied with, the Director of Public Works shall within ten (10) working days of the date the corrected final map was submitted to him by the subdivider certify his approval on the original tracings and the blueline cloth prints of said map. Following the certification of the Director of Public Works, the final map shall be transmitted to the City Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.55. - ACTION BY CITY COUNCIL: 
Upon receipt of the final map and related documents, the City Clerk shall put the matter on the next available regular agenda of the Council. The Council shall either approve, conditionally approve, or disapprove such map in accordance with the provisions of the Subdivision Map Act and of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.56. - ADDITIONAL GUARANTEES: 
In addition to the requirements set forth in the Subdivision Map Act, the subdivider shall at the time of filing of the executed and endorsed final map with the City Clerk, furnish guarantee of title or a letter from an approved title company certifying that the signatures of all persons whose consent is required to pass clear title to the land being subdivided appear on the proper certificates and are correctly shown on said map, both as to consent to the making of the map and to the necessary affidavits of dedication. Such guarantee shall be issued for the benefit of the City, and shall be in full force and effect until recordation of such map. The subdivider shall also furnish grant deeds for any land or easements required to be dedicated to the City as part of the subdivision, but which have not been dedicated on the final map. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.57. - RECORDATION OF MAP: 
Upon approval of the final map and related documents, the City Clerk shall transmit such map and documents to the clerk of the Board of Supervisors for recordation. Related documents shall include but shall not be limited to covenants, conditions and restrictions, and any required improvement agreement. After recordation of the final map and related documents, the subdivider shall file one set of reproducible polyester base tracings, and two (2) sets of covenants and restrictions with recordation indicia thereon with the Department of Public Works. One set of prints from such tracings shall be transmitted to the Planning Department. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Secs. 30.58—30.64. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE V. - MISCELLANEOUS REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 30.65. - PUBLIC HEARING AND NOTICE: 
The Planning Commission shall conduct a public hearing for each tentative parcel map and for each tentative map for which an application for exceptions from the standards of this Chapter have been made. Notice thereof shall be given as provided in section 66451.3 of the Government Code; and further, owners of record of adjacent lands shall be notified in the manner provided in section 49.3 of the Zoning Ordinance. Any interested person may appear at such hearing and shall be provided the opportunity to make comments on such tentative parcel map or tentative map. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.66. - EXTENSION OF TENTATIVE PARCEL MAP AND TENTATIVE MAP APPROVALS: 
Any subdivider who desires an extension of the expiration date for a tentative parcel map or tentative map shall file a written application therefor with the Planning Director at least forty-five (45) days before the approval or conditional approval of a map is due to expire. The application shall state the reasons for requesting the extension. In granting the extension, new conditions for approval of such tentative parcel map or tentative map may be imposed and existing conditions may be revised. An extension or extensions of a tentative parcel map or tentative map expiration date shall not exceed a total of two (2) years from the date of the initial approval of the tentative parcel map or tentative map. Modifications of a tentative parcel map or tentative map after approval or conditional approval shall not extend the time limits imposed by this Section. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.67. - FAILURE TO FILE PARCEL MAP OR FINAL MAP: 
Failure to file a parcel map or final map with the City in accordance with the applicable provisions of this Chapter within the prescribed time limit shall terminate all proceedings. After all time limits for the filing thereof shall have elapsed, any subdivision of the same land shall require the filing of a new tentative parcel map or tentative map and the payment of the required fees in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.68. - APPEALS; ADVISORY AGENCY: 
For all actions taken pursuant to this Chapter 30, any interested person may appeal from any action of the Subdivision Committee, the Community Development Director, the Planning Manager, or the Planning Commission, whichever is applicable, to the Planning Commission with respect to determinations by the Subdivision Committee, Community Development Director, and Planning Manager and to the City Council with respect to final determinations by the Planning Commission, provided, however, the decision of the Planning Commission on matters appealed to it is final and is not subject to appeal. All appeals must be filed within ten (10) days of the action taken pursuant to this Chapter 30 and shall be filed, processed and heard in accordance with Sections 1.45.9 and 1.45.10. All such appeals and the hearings thereon shall be conducted in the manner provided by Government Code section 66452.5. Every such appeal shall be accompanied by a filing fee established pursuant to Section 30.70." 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79) 
(Ord. No. 2374, § 24, 1-9-12; Ord. No. 2437, § 2, 6-12-17)  
Sec. 30.69. - EXCEPTIONS: 
Exceptions to any of the requirements of this Chapter may be granted by the Planning Commission. An application requesting an exception shall state the grounds justifying the granting of such exception. Such application may be filed with the preliminary design map application, if such map is submitted. Such application shall be filed, however, with the tentative parcel map or tentative map and shall be considered by the Subdivision Committee or the Plan Review Committee, as the case may be. The application requesting an exception with the recommendations of the Subdivision Committee or the Plan Review Committee shall be forwarded to the Planning Commission with the related tentative parcel map or tentative map. 
The Planning Commission shall review the application requesting an exception and the recommendation of the Subdivision Committee or the Plan Review Committee at the time the Planning Commission considers the tentative parcel map or tentative map. After making such review, the Planning Commission may grant one or more exceptions if it makes all of the following findings: 
A.  The property is of such shape or size, or is affected by such topographical conditions, or is subject to such title limitations of record that it is impossible or impracticable for the subdivider to comply with the requirement with which exception is taken. 
B.  The exception is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the subdivider. 
C.  The granting of the exception will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the vicinity of the subject property. 
In granting an exception, the Planning Commission may impose such conditions as will substantially secure the objectives of this Chapter. Where an exception is authorized, the performance of any conditions imposed in connection therewith may be secured by such guarantee as may reasonably be deemed necessary by the Planning Commission. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.70. - MAP PROCESSING FEE; APPEAL FEE: 
An application for the processing of any land division, whether a subdivision or not, and an appeal from an advisory agency decision, shall be accompanied by a reasonable filing fee in an amount as may be established by resolution of the Council. Such filing fees shall not be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.71. - DEPOSITS: 
In addition to such fees as may be established pursuant to the provisions of Section 30.70, the subdivider shall deposit such funds as the Director of Public Works may determine will be necessary to defray partially the actual costs of conducting investigations, reviewing improvement plans, recording of applicable plans and performing of construction inspection and testing services which will be incurred by the City in the processing of maps and in the approving of subdivision improvements required in connection with a project. Failure of the subdivider to supply the necessary documents shall automatically result in forfeiture of ten percent (10%) of any funds deposited and not previously encumbered. 
Costs shall be based on average hourly rates of the City personnel necessary for processing the aforementioned documents and for providing the required services in connection with a project. The method of charging pro rata costs for such services and the hourly rates to be applied for providing such services shall be established by resolution of the City Council. 
If the amount of deposit initially estimated by the Director of Public Works to be required to defray the anticipated costs of providing such services is insufficient to cover the actual costs of the City, the subdivider shall make an additional deposit sufficient to defray the revised costs. Failure to do so shall be grounds for ceasing all further work on the project. All funds on deposit after defraying all reasonable costs of the City in providing such services shall be returned to the subdivider within thirty (30) days after recordation of the final map or parcel map, as the case may be, or after required improvements have been constructed and accepted by the City, or upon withdrawal of a map as provided in this Chapter. The subdivider shall deposit all required funds with the City prior to commencement of work on any portion of a subdivision or other division of land prior to filing a parcel map or a final map. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.72. - WAIVER OF DIRECT ACCESS TO STREETS: 
The subdivider, as a condition for acceptance of any dedication or offer of dedication of a street, may be required to include a waiver of direct access to such street from any property shown on a final map or parcel map as abutting thereon. If the dedication is accepted, such waiver shall become effective in accordance with its provisions and the Subdivision Map Act. Such "access" may include, but shall not be limited to, provision for vehicular, pedestrian, bicycle or equestrian forms of transportation or locomotion. The term "street" as used in this Section may be interpreted to include existing as well as new streets, highways, freeways, expressways, parkways, and pedestrian paths or hiking trails, cycling and equestrian paths. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.73. - REQUIREMENTS FOR DEDICATION FOR STREETS, ALLEYS, DRAINAGE, PUBLIC UTILITY EASEMENTS AND OTHER PUBLIC EASEMENTS: 
As a condition of approval of a final map or parcel map, the subdivider shall dedicate or make an irrevocable offer of dedication of all parcels of land within the subdivision that are required for streets, alleys, including access rights and abutter's rights, drainage, public utility easements, and other public easements. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.74. - PAYMENT OF FEES REQUIRED FOR DRAINAGE AND SEWER FACILITIES: 
Prior to the filing of any parcel map or final map the subdivider shall pay, or cause to be paid, any fees as may be established by resolution of the Council for defraying the estimated costs of constructing planned drainage facilities for the removal of surface and storm waters from local or neighborhood areas, and for sewer connections and other utility and sewer facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Secs. 30.75—30.78. - RESERVED:  
Sec. 30.79. - IMPROVEMENT SECURITY—REQUIRED: 
All improvement security required in connection with a division of land shall be provided in a manner which is in compliance with the Subdivision Map Act. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.80. - IMPROVEMENT SECURITY—AMOUNT: 
Security to guarantee the performance of any act or agreement shall be in the following amounts: 
A.  One hundred percent (100%) of the total estimated cost of the improvements or of the act to be performed, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the act or an agreement to construct the improvements. 
B.  One hundred percent (100%) of the total estimated costs of the improvements or the performance of the required act, securing payment to the contractor, and any subcontractors or persons furnishing labor, materials or equipment in connection with the performance of such act or construction of such improvements. Such security shall provide that if the subdivider, contractor, or any subcontractor fails to pay any of the persons named in section 3181 of the Civil Code, or the amounts due under the Unemployment Insurance Code with respect to work or labor performed by any such claimant, or for any amounts required to be deducted, withheld, and paid over to the Franchise Tax Board from wages of employees of the contractor and his subcontractors pursuant to section 18806 of the Revenue and Taxation Code, with respect to such labor and work that the surety or sureties will pay for the same, and also, in case suit is brought upon the bond, a reasonable attorney's fee, to be fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
C.  Ten percent (10%) of the total estimated cost of the improvements, or of the act to be performed, conditioned upon the guarantee of the improvements or act to be performed for a period of one year following completion and acceptance thereof against any defect in the improvements or object of the act to be performed or in the material to be furnished, as required in Section 30.88. 
The improvement security described in A and B above shall provide, respectively, that such security is for the faithful performance and securing payment for furnishing labor, materials, or equipment required by any changes or alterations in the work, to the extent that such changes or alterations do not exceed ten percent (10%) of the original estimated cost of the improvement. Such improvement security shall also provide that the City may recover reasonable expenses, including attorney's fees, incurred by the City in successfully enforcing the security to complete such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.81. - IMPROVEMENT SECURITY—SPECIAL ASSESSMENT PROCEEDINGS; REDUCTION: 
In the event the required subdivision improvements are financed and installed pursuant to special assessment proceedings, the subdivider may apply to the Council for a reduction in the amount of improvement security which would ordinarily have been required for such project but for the amount to be provided by such subdivider in connection with such special assessment. The Council may grant such reduction if it finds that adequate assessments to provide for such improvements for a project have been made by such subdivider in connection with such special assessment proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.82. - IMPROVEMENT SECURITY—RELEASE: 
All improvement security shall be released in the following manner: 
A.  Security given for faithful performance of any act or agreement shall be released upon the final completion and acceptance of the act or work. However, the Director of Public Works may release a portion of the security in conjunction with the acceptance of the performance of part of the act or work as the improvements or project progresses upon application therefor by the subdivider; provided, however, that no such release shall be for an amount less than ten percent (10%) of the total improvement security given for faithful performance of the act or work and that the security shall not be reduced to an amount less than seventy-five percent (75%) of the total improvement security given for faithful performance until final completion and acceptance of the act or work. In no event shall the Director of Public Works authorize a release of the improvement security which would reduce such security to an amount below that required to guarantee the completion of the act or work and any other obligation imposed by this Chapter, the Subdivision Map Act, or an improvement agreement for a project. 
B.  Security given to secure payment to the contractor, his subcontractors and to persons furnishing labor, materials or equipment, may, six (6) months after the completion and acceptance of the act or work, be reduced to an amount equal to the amount of all claims therefor filed and of which notice has been given to the City, plus an amount reasonably determined by the Council upon recommendation of the Director of Public Works to be required to assure the performance of any other obligations secured thereby. The balance of the security shall be released by the Council upon recommendation of the Director of Public Works, and upon the settlement of all such claims and obligations for which the security was given. 
C.  Security given to guarantee work for a time period shall be released only upon the expiration of that time period. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.83. - SOILS REPORT: 
For all divisions of land for which a parcel map or a final map is required, with the exception of a map for a merger or reversions to acreage, a preliminary soils report, prepared or approved by a civil engineer registered in this State, based on adequate test borings shall be submitted to the Director of Public Works and to the Building Official in accordance with the provisions of this Section. 
Such preliminary soils report shall be submitted prior to the approval of the tentative parcel map or tentative map if the land to be divided has been designated in the seismic element of the general plan as land subject to landslides, or has otherwise been determined by the City to contain potentially hazardous soils conditions, or if the land to be divided is located on a hillside area having slopes of fifteen percent (15%) or more grade. In all other instances a preliminary soils report shall be submitted prior to the approval of the parcel map or final map. 
The primary soils report may be waived by the Building Official if he has knowledge of the soils condition of the land to be divided and, upon that basis, he determines that no preliminary soils report is necessary. 
If the City has knowledge of, or the preliminary soils report indicates, the presence of critically expansive soils or other soils problems which, if not corrected, would lead to structural defects in any building to be constructed on a site, a soils investigation shall be performed for the overall subdivision by a civil engineer registered in this State. The report of such investigation shall recommend the corrective actions required to prevent structural damage to each building to be constructed on building sites within the subdivision. If in the opinion of the Building Official, the soils condition within the subdivision exhibit a high degree of complexity, the Building Official may require detailed investigations on several or all lots of the proposed subdivision. The Building Official, as a condition for the issuance of any building permit, may require that the recommended corrective action of a civil engineer be incorporated in to the construction of each building within the proposed subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.84. - GEOLOGIC REPORT: 
For all divisions of land for which a parcel map or final map is required which land has been designated in the seismic element of the general plan as containing hazardous soil conditions or which otherwise has been determined by the Building Official as containing potentially hazardous conditions, a preliminary geologic report, prepared or approved by a geologist registered in this State and certified in engineering geology shall be incorporated in any environmental review documents for such project. 
If such preliminary geologic report indicates the presence of geologic problems which, if not corrected or adequately planned for in the design of a subdivision, would result in structural defects in any building to be constructed on a site, a geologic investigation for the affected parts of the land division shall be performed and a report of the findings shall be submitted with the tentative parcel map or the tentative map. Such geologic report, which shall be prepared in connection with any required soils report, shall indicate if the area is suitable for development, and if found suitable, shall specify what actions must be taken prior to approval of a parcel map or final map, as the case may be, and/or prior to the issuance of any building permits. If the area is found unsuitable for development, the application shall be denied. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.85. - FINAL MAP; MONUMENTS: 
At the time of making the survey for the final map, the engineer or surveyor shall set sufficient durable monuments to conform with the standards described in section 8771 of the Business and Professions Code. 
The engineer or surveyor shall also set such additional monuments as the Director of Public Works shall require. All monuments necessary to establish the exterior boundaries of the subdivision shall be set or referenced prior to the recordation of the final map. Interior monuments shall be set in accordance with the provisions of sections 66496, 66497 and 66498 of the Government Code. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.86. - IMPROVEMENTS; GENERAL REQUIREMENTS: 
The subdivider shall perform the following responsibilities in connection with improvements for the proposed subdivision: 
A.  The subdivider shall improve, or agree to improve, all public or private streets, pathways, trails and easements, and to install such other improvements and utilities required by this Chapter which are necessary for the general use of lot owners in the proposed subdivision, and for local neighborhood traffic and drainage which is necessitated by the construction of the proposed subdivision. 
B.  The subdivider shall submit a complete set of plans, profiles, cross sections and specifications for the proposed improvements which shall be in conformity with the current design standards in force and the standard specifications of the City, on reproducible material, in a form acceptable to the Director of Public Works for his review and approval. The plan scales and the sheet sizes shall be approved by the Director of Public Works. If the Director of Public Works approves the improvement plans and specifications, he shall so certify on the face of the reproducible material. 
C.  The Director of Public Works, or other representatives of the City shall have the right to enter upon the site of the improvements for the purpose of inspecting the site, the improvements, and the materials to be utilized in connection therewith. The Director of Public Works shall be furnished with such samples of materials as he may require for testing to determine the acceptability of such materials. 
D.  No improvement work shall be commenced until plans and specifications have been approved by the appropriate City official whose approval is required for the improvement work. Improvements shall be installed in accordance with the approved plans and specifications, to permanent line and grade, to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works who shall inspect such work. All work shall be subject to such inspections as he deems necessary. All improvements shall comply with the current design standards and the standard specifications of the City in effect at the time of approval. The burden of proof shall lie with the subdivider to show that alternate designs, materials and specifications are equal to such standards or specifications. All grading and/or major vegetation removal in connection with the subdivision shall conform to the provisions of Section 30.90. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.87. - MINIMUM IMPROVEMENTS: 
The minimum subdivision improvements that shall be required, if applicable to the proposed subdivision, unless specifically excepted by the Subdivision Committee or the Planning Commission as the case may be, shall be as follows: 
A.  Grading, curbs and gutters, paving, and monuments within street rights-of-way. 
B.  Driveways, sidewalks or pedestrian paths and similar features. 
C.  Street name signs, traffic warning signs, required traffic and crosswalk lines, and similar devices, all in accordance with standard specifications of the City. 
D.  Storm drainage system, including on and off site grading and drainage structures. 
E.  Water system including fire hydrants with required appurtenances. 
F.  Sanitary sewer system and appurtenant structures, laterals for each lot including such connections as are required. (Location and depth of such laterals shall be indicated on construction drawings.) 
G.  Street tree and other street plantings which shall be installed by the City and the cost of which shall be reimbursed by the subdivider. 
H.  All communications and electrical distribution facilities, including fire alarm boxes. 
I.  Gas distribution system. 
J.  Street lighting system. 
K.  Underground ducting and appurtenant structures for traffic signal systems. 
L.  Earth retaining walls. 
M.  Any other improvements which may have been attached as conditions to an approved planned development permit. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.88. - GUARANTEES: 
The subdivider shall guarantee the workmanship of all improvements installed by him or under his direction, and shall correct all deficiencies in the design and/or construction of any improvement for a period of one year from the date of acceptance of such improvements by the City. Such guarantee shall include any repairs to such improvements caused by or necessitated by erosion or landslides. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.89. - COMPLETION PLANS: 
Upon completion of the construction of all improvements, the subdivider shall amend the improvement plans to show improvements "as built." Such "as built" plans shall be on suitable reproducible material. Upon receipt of the "as built" plans, the Director of Public Works shall recommend formal acceptance of the improvements by the Council when he is fully satisfied that they have been installed in complete conformance with the provisions of this Chapter and with the "as built" plans. Elevations related to City datum shall be shown on the "as built" plans wherever a monument required in Section 30.85 above is located within a street right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.90. - GRADING, EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL PLANS: 
Plans and other documents required under Section 30.86B shall include precise grading plans and specifications. Where, in the opinion of the Director of Public Works, the site possesses a high soil erosion potential, the plans and specifications shall also show erosion control measures to be undertaken. 
Such plans and specifications for erosion control shall include one or more of the following measures to prevent soil erosion and to prevent sedimentation or damage to adjacent property: 
A.  Special slope grading. 
B.  Installation of retaining walls, under drains and similar structures. 
C.  Special facilities for collection, conductance, retention, or diversion of surface waters. 
D.  Preservation and enhancement of vegetative cover on undisturbed existing slopes. 
E.  Planting graded slopes with suitable vegetative cover. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.91. - UNDERGROUNDING CATV SYSTEMS: 
The subdivider shall contact the applicable franchisee of a CATV franchise in the City to determine the requirements of the franchise for the installation of a CATV underground system for that subdivision and shall perform its construction activities in a manner which will facilitate the installation of such system by the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 1893, § 1, 4-2-84)  
Sec. 30.92. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VI. - SCHOOL SITE DEDICATION 
 
Sec. 30.93. - REQUIREMENTS: 
As a condition of approval of a final map, a subdivider, who develops or completes the development of one or more subdivisions within the Redwood City and/or the Belmont Elementary School Districts, shall dedicate to the appropriate school district such lands as the Council shall deem to be necessary for the purpose of constructing schools thereon to assure the residents of the subdivision adequate public elementary school service. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.94. - PROCEDURE: 
The requirement of dedication shall be imposed at the time of approval of the tentative map. If within thirty (30) days after the requirement of dedication is imposed by the City, the Redwood City or Belmont School District does not offer to enter into a binding commitment with the subdivider to accept the dedication, the requirement shall be automatically terminated. The required dedication may be made any time before, concurrently with, or up to sixty (60) days after the filing of the final map on any portion of the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.95. - PAYMENT TO SUBDIVIDER FOR SCHOOL SITE DEDICATION: 
The Redwood City or the Belmont Elementary School District shall, if it accepts the dedication, repay to the subdivider or his successors the original cost to the subdivider of the dedicated land, plus a sum equal to the total of the following amounts: 
A.  The cost of any improvements to the dedicated land since acquisition by the subdivider. 
B.  The taxes assessed against the dedicated land from the date of the school district's offer to enter into the binding commitment to accept the dedication. 
C.  Any other costs incurred by the subdivider in maintenance of such dedicated land, including interest costs incurred on any loan covering such land. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.96. - EXEMPTIONS: 
The provisions of this Article shall not be applicable to a subdivider who has owned the land being subdivided for more than ten (10) years prior to the filing of the tentative map pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.97. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VII. - RESERVATION FOR PUBLIC USES 
 
Sec. 30.98. - REQUIREMENTS: 
As a condition of approval of a map, the subdivider shall reserve sites, appropriate in area and location, for parks, recreational facilities, fire stations, libraries or other public uses according to the standards and formula contained in this Article and/or according to referenced documents contained in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.99. - STANDARDS AND FORMULA FOR RESERVATIONS: 
The reserved area must be of such size and shape as to permit the balance of the property within which the reservation is located to develop in an orderly and efficient manner. The reserved area shall conform to such specific plan as may pertain to the proposed division of land, and the general plan, and shall be in such multiples of streets and parcels as to permit an efficient division of the reserved area in the event that said area is not required within the prescribed period. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.100. - PROCEDURE: 
To perfect an acquisition authorized herein, the public agency for whose benefit an area has been reserved shall at the time of approval of the final map or parcel map, enter into a binding agreement to acquire such reserved area within two (2) years after the completion and acceptance of all improvements, unless such period of time is extended by mutual agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.101. - PAYMENT: 
The purchase price shall be the fair market value of the reserved area at the time of the filing of the tentative map or tentative parcel map plus the taxes assessed against such reserved area from the date of the reservation and any other costs incurred by the subdivider in the maintenance of such reserved area, including interest costs incurred on any loan covering such reserved area. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.102. - TERMINATION: 
If the public agency for whose benefit an area has been reserved does not enter into a binding agreement as specified in Section 30.100, the reservation of such area shall automatically terminate. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.103. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE VIII. - REVERSION TO ACREAGE 
 
Sec. 30.104. - INITIATION OF PROCEEDINGS BY OWNERS: 
Proceedings to revert subdivided property to acreage may be initiated by petition of all of the owners of record of the subject lots. The petition shall be in a form prescribed by the Planning Director. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.105. - INITIATION OF PROCEEDINGS BY CITY COUNCIL: 
The Council on its own motion may initiate proceedings to revert property to acreage. 
(Ord. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.106. - DATA FOR REVISION TO ACREAGE: 
A petition shall contain the following: 
A.  Evidence of title to the real property; and 
B.  Evidence of the consent of all of the owners with a record title interest(s) in the subject property; or 
C.  Evidence that none of the improvements required to be made have been made within two (2) years from the date the parcel map or final map was filed for record, or within the time allowed by agreement for completion of the improvements, whichever is later; or 
D.  Evidenced that no lots shown on the parcel map or final map have been sold within five (5) years from the date such parcel or final map was filed for record; or 
E.  A tentative parcel map in the form prescribed by Section 30.17 if required by the Planning Director; and 
F.  A parcel map or final map, in the form prescribed by the Director of Public Works which delineates dedications which will not be vacated and dedications which are required as a condition to reversion. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.107. - FEES: 
If the proceedings are initiated pursuant to Section 30.104, the person or persons who requested the Council to initiate the proceedings shall pay a fee established pursuant to the provisions of Section 30.70. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.108. - PROCEEDINGS BEFORE THE COUNCIL: 
A public hearing shall be held by the Council on all petitions for reversions to acreage. Notice of the public hearing shall be given as provided in section 66451.3 of the Government Code. The Council may give such other notice as it deems necessary. 
The Council may approve a reversion to acreage upon making the findings specified in section 66499.16 of the Government Code. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.109. - RELEASE OF SECURITIES; DELIVERY OF PARCEL MAP OR FINAL MAP: 
After the hearing before the Council and approval of the reversion to acreage, the parcel map or final map shall be delivered to the County Recorder. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.110. - EFFECT OF FILING REVERSION MAP WITH THE COUNTY RECORDER: 
A reversion to acreage shall be effective upon the parcel map or final map being filed for record by the County Recorder. Upon filing, all dedications and offers of dedication not shown on the parcel map or final map for reversion shall be of no further force and effect. 
(Ord. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.111. - MERGER OF SUBDIVIDED LANDS: 
Subdivided lands may be merged and resubdivided without reverting to acreage by compliance with all the provisions of this Chapter and the provisions of Section 66499.20-3/4 of the Government Code. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Secs. 30.112, 30.113. - RESERVED:  
ARTICLE IX. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 30.114. - PURPOSE; MODIFICATIONS: 
The design standards herein set forth are hereby declared to be the minimum acceptable design standards for all divisions of land; provided, however, that if the appropriate advisory agency finds that a greater or lesser standard proposed by the subdivider would be in the public interest, said agency may approve such modification to said standards. The burden of proof as to whether the public interest would be so served by a proposed modification from the adopted standards shall lie with the subdivider. 
The purposes of these standards are as follows: 
A.  Promotion of public safety; 
B.  Implementation of applicable general plan goals, principles and standards; 
C.  Promotion of a higher and more uniform quality of living environment throughout the community; and 
D.  Protection of the land purchaser and of the general public from unnecessary expense due to the necessity of correcting substandard and faulty design features. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.115. - CONFORMITY TO SPECIFIC AREA PLANS: 
The design standards for a division shall be consistent with the design intent of the specific areas plan, if any, which pertains to the area within which the division lies. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.116. - MISCELLANEOUS STANDARDS: 
A.  Sewage Disposal: The size of mains, laterals, and appurtenances for public sanitary sewers shall be in accordance with City specifications. The Department of Public Works may require the oversizing of such facilities to serve property beyond a proposed division. 
B.  Water Supply: The source of water for all divisions in the City shall be the City water system. The sizing of mains and service lines, and the design of the system shall be in accordance with City specifications and shall be subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works and the Fire Chief. The location of all fire hydrants shall also be subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works and the Fire Chief. 
C.  Fire Alarm Boxes: The location, type and number of fire alarm boxes shall be subject to the approval of the Fire Chief and shall be installed by the subdivider. 
D.  Public Utilities: Utility easements for gas, underground electrical and communications distribution services shall be provided by the subdivider. Unless the subdivision is located within a previously platted area with rear lot line easements, all such easements shall be along the street frontage. All utility distribution service shall be underground in residential and commercial subdivisions, except as follows: 
1.  Pedestal mounted terminal boxes and meter cabinets. 
2.  Metal or wooden poles for street lights. 
3.  Electrical distribution lines carrying in excess of 34.5 kv. 
The subdivider shall be responsible for coordination of design and installation standards with the affected utilities. 
E.  Drainage: General requirements for drainage are as follows: 
1.  Drainage structures shall be designed so as to protect lots and streets from a 100-year flood hazard as detailed in the City standard specifications. 
2.  Wherever the topography permits, drainage from individual lots shall be toward the street or toward a natural drainage course. For downhill side lots in hillside divisions, drainage shall be designed to minimize the effect thereof on lots located at lower elevations. 
3.  Wherever a natural or a planned drainage course traverses a subdivision, a maintenance and/or open space easement shall be dedicated by the subdivider for the safe disposal of storm waters. 
4.  Drainage structures shall be designed and installed to a grade to the approval of the Director of Public Works. He may require installation of such access and safety features on such structures as he deems necessary to provide and maintain adequate drainage. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.117. - LOT DESIGN: 
All divisions shall contain the following lot design features: 
A.  Suitability for Designated Purpose: All divisions shall create lots capable of being built upon in accordance with applicable development regulations. No division shall create lots which are impracticable or hazardous for use due to steepness of terrain, location of water courses, seismic hazards, earth movement, size, shape, or other physical conditions. 
B.  Size, Shape and Frontage: The minimum area and dimensions shall conform to standard requirements of the Zoning Ordinance or to any approved planned development permit. Where unusual topography exists, lot area shall be increased in accordance with the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance. Lot depths shall generally not exceed two and one-half (2 ½) times their average width. 
C.  Angle of Side Lines to Street: The side lines of all lots shall be perpendicular to the street the lot faces, and shall be approximately radial to a street where it is curved. The Planning Director may recommend exceptions to such standards if he determines that strict compliance will be impractical. However, in no event shall any intersecting side lot line form an acute angle with the street of less than seventy degrees (70º). 
D.  Divided Lot Prohibited: No lot created under this Chapter shall be divided by a City boundary line, nor shall it be effectively divided by lots or parcels of land so that the principal parts of the lot are connected by a corridor of less than fifty feet (50') wide. 
E.  Double Frontage Prohibited: No lot created under this Chapter in a residentially zoned district shall have a double frontage except in the case of a corner lot. The Planning Director may recommend an exception to this standard. 
F.  Panhandle Lots: Panhandle lots (i.e., lots for which street frontage or access width is less than the minimum required) will not be approved as part of a division unless the subdivider shows that preexisting development in the vicinity of the division or unusual topography of the division justifies a panhandle lot. Every panhandle lot which may be approved shall have frontage on either a recorded public or private street of not less than thirty five feet (35'), and a building site shall be located within two hundred feet (200') from the street frontage of such lot. 
G.  Lot Line Alignment: Rear and interior lot lines shall be free of excessive jogs in alignment. 
H.  Passive or Natural Heating or Cooling: Consideration shall be given to future passive or natural heating or cooling opportunities in lot design. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.118. - STREET DESIGN: 
All proposed streets shall comply with the following criteria: 
A.  Street Design: The proposed street or highway design for a division shall conform to the circulation element of the general plan and to any specific plan pertaining to such division, and shall be approved by the Director of Public Works. 
B.  Street Widths: The minimum width of the several classes of streets and highways shall conform to the schedule contained in this Section; provided, however, where a planned development permit for the subject area has been approved, or where the Subdivision Committee, or the Plan Review Committee, as the case may be, finds that it would be in the public interest to provide an exception to the precise standards contained herein such agency shall recommend a modification to such standards to the Planning Commission. Increased widths may be required where streets are to serve commercial or industrial property, or where present or anticipated traffic conditions warrant such increase. 
Schedule of standard street widths: 
1.  Parkway: Six (6) lanes divided—140 foot right-of-way—92 foot roadway width, including 16 foot median. 
2.  Parkway: Four (4) lanes divided—116 foot right-of-way—68 foot roadway width, including 16 foot median. 
3.  Arterial: Four (4) lanes divided—104 foot right-of-way—84 foot roadway width, including 14 foot median and two (2) four foot bike lanes. 
4.  Collector: Two (2) lanes—68 foot right-of-way—48 foot roadway width, including two (2) four foot bike lanes. 
5.  Commercial Street: Two (2) lanes—60 foot right-of-way—40 foot roadway width. 
6.  Industrial Street: Two (2) lanes—60 foot right-of-way—40 foot roadway width. 
7.  Local Street: Two (2) lanes—54 foot right-of-way—34 foot roadway width. 
8.  Hillside Street: Two (2) lanes—40 foot right-of-way—24 foot roadway width from center line to center line of two-foot roll gutter with parking provided on two (2) eight-foot paved shoulders. 
9.  Service or frontage road not exceeding one thousand feet (1,000') in length: Two (2) lanes—48 foot right-of-way—32 foot roadway. 
If, because of adjacent land use, or the type or design of development, on-street parking is determined by the Director of Public Works to be unnecessary on one side of a street, the standard right-of-way width and roadway width may be reduced by six feet (6'). If the Director of Public Works determines no on-street parking is required on either side of the street, the above widths may be reduced by twelve feet (12'). 
C.  Turnarounds: All turnarounds shall have a radius of at least forty feet (40') to face of curb. The minimum radius for turnarounds in commercial or industrial subdivisions may be recommended by the Director of Public Works to be increased because of anticipated traffic usage. The maximum length of cul-de-sac street shall be two hundred fifty feet (250'), unless the Subdivision Committee or the Planning Commission, as the case may be, approves an extension thereof because of topography or preexisting development in the vicinity of the division. 
D.  Grades, Curves, Sight Distances: Grades, curves and sight distances shall be subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works to ensure the safety of drivers and pedestrians, and to avoid excessive grading or vegetation removal. Maximum grade for all streets other than local or hillside streets shall be seven percent (7%), the maximum grade for local or hillside streets shall be twelve percent (12%). A grade of fifteen percent (15%) may be permitted by the Director of Public Works if he determines that special topographical conditions or other exceptional circumstances relating to the property within a proposed division justify such grade. 
E.  Street Pattern: Street patterns shall conform to applicable principles in the circulation element of the general plan, and shall, wherever appropriate, provide for the development of adjoining areas. The street pattern shall also conform to the following principles and standards: 
1.  Proposed major arterials and collector streets shall be continuous and in alignment with existing or platted streets with which they are to connect. Center lines of connecting streets not in alignment shall be offset a minimum of one hundred fifty feet (150'). 
2.  Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the division whenever it is determined such extension is necessary for traffic circulation and coordination of the proposed division with adjoining divisions or the development of adjoining properties. 
3.  Where a street must be stubended at a boundary line of the division, a one foot nonaccess easement at the end of the street shall be deeded to the City. Such strip shall not be improved and a barrier shall be erected on such strip subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works. Where four (4) or more lots or dwelling units have their sole access to the street system of the City by means of the street which is stubended, a temporary turnaround within the public right-of-way or a temporary connection to another street shall be provided by the subdivider. 
4.  Proposed streets shall intersect at approximately ninety degree (90º) angles. If the Director of Public Works determines that topography, traffic design, or other factors of such development indicate the need for modifying this standard, such standard may be modified up to fifteen degrees (15º). 
5.  Corners of both curbs and property lines shall be rounded. Minimum radius at the property line shall be twenty feet (20'). Greater radii may be required where necessitated by projected traffic conditions or by intersection of streets at less than ninety degree (90º) angles. 
6.  Excessively long and straight or steep streets in residential areas shall be avoided. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.119. - STREET NAMING: 
Streets which are continuations of existing streets shall bear the names of such existing streets. Names of new streets shall be submitted to the Planning Director who shall submit them to postal authorities and to the Fire Chief for review to avoid duplication of names within the areas served by the safety services and others. Final approval of all street names shall be the responsibility of the Planning Director. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.120. - PEDESTRIAN/BICYCLE PATHS: 
A subdivider shall be required to dedicate and develop pedestrian/bicycle paths when necessitated by traffic safety and for the purpose of providing safe access to schools, parks, playgrounds, and other community facilities. Such paths shall be a minimum of ten feet (10') wide. At the option of the City, pedestrian/bicycle paths may be combined with other easements or rights-of-way when such easements are compatible with the purposes of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.121. - STREET LIGHTING: 
Street lighting shall be appropriate to the proposed intensity of use of the street facility and the character of the area to be served. The amount of street lighting shall be consistent with principles of energy conservation and optimum public safety, and shall be subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.122. - STREET TREES AND PLANTINGS: 
Street trees of a species approved by the Director of Parks and Recreation shall be planted at a maximum of fifty feet (50') apart, but each lot shall have at least one such tree planted thereon or therefor. Street trees shall be planted in an approved planting easement or an approved planting area within the right-of-way. Final location of each street tree shall be determined by the Director of Parks and Recreation. Where the character and design of a street require, as determined by the Director of Parks and Recreation, plantings in addition to street trees shall be provided by a subdivider. All such planting materials shall be subject to the approval of the Director of Parks and Recreation, and street trees shall be installed by City personnel under his direction. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.123. - SIDEWALKS: 
Sidewalks shall be installed to the standard specifications of the City. Where steep topography or unique local conditions on local access streets make provision of sidewalks impractical, as determined by the Director of Public Works or the Planning Director, either may recommend alternatives to the Subdivision Committee or the Planning Commission. Such alternatives shall give consideration to providing a reasonable level of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.124. - CURBS AND GUTTERS: 
Curbs and gutters shall be installed to the standard specifications of the City. Where unusual site conditions or preexisting development in the vicinity of a proposed division make conformance to such standards impractical, as determined by the Director of Public Works or the Planning Director, either may recommend to the Subdivision Committee or the Planning Commission that either no curb and gutter be required or that an alternate design be approved. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
Sec. 30.125. - RAIL CROSSINGS: 
Additional crossings of main rail lines are to be avoided. Where no feasible alternative to the creation of a new railroad crossing exists because of the need to provide access for major circulation within a proposed division, the subdivider shall provide such crossing at his expense. The subdivider shall be responsible for preparation of all documents necessary for filing an application with the State Public Utilities Commission for a permit to establish and improve such crossing. 
(Ord. No. 1774, § 2, 2-5-79)  
ARTICLE X. - ENFORCEMENT AND JUDICIAL REVIEW 
 
Sec. 30.126. - PROHIBITION AND PENALTY: 
A.
